The main purpose of this project is â˜‘ï¸To provide a seamless online shopping experience for NMG customers.â˜‘ï¸To manage product listings, pricing, inventory, and offers efficiently.â˜‘ï¸ To handle secure user authentication, cart management, checkout, and payments.â˜‘ï¸ To support high traffic, fast search results, and smooth order processing and alsoâ˜‘ï¸ To integrate with warehouses, delivery partners, and internal ERP systems.â˜‘ï¸ In this Project, we have different modules likeâ˜‘ï¸ User Management Module=>under this we have - Login, registration, profile, address book.â˜‘ï¸ Product Catalog Module=>under this we have - Category pages, product details, filters, search.â˜‘ï¸ Inventory Management Module=> under this we have - Stock updates, availability, SKU management.â˜‘ï¸ Cart & Wishlist Module=> under this we have - Add/remove items, update quantities, save for later.â˜‘ï¸Checkout & Payments Module=> Address selection, payment gateway, order summary.â˜‘ï¸ Order Management Module=> Order creation, tracking, returns/refunds.â˜‘ï¸ Offers & Promotions Module=> Coupons, discount rules, seasonal campaigns.â˜‘ï¸ Admin Portal Module=> Product upload, pricing updates, inventory dashboard. *** I used - Backend Skills like (Node JS + Express JS + Microservices + MySQL)-âœŒï¸ Developed RESTful APIs for products, cart, auth, orders.âœŒï¸ Followed Microservices architecture for scalability.âœŒï¸ Used Express JS for routing, middleware, validations.âœŒï¸ Implemented JWT authentication & session handling.âœŒï¸ Used MySQL for user data, inventory, orders, transactions.âœŒï¸ Implemented async operations, caching, pagination.âœŒï¸ *** I used Frontend Skills like (React JS + Redux + HTML + CSS + JavaScript)âœŒï¸ Built responsive UI using React JS.âœŒï¸ Managed state using Redux Toolkit. Implemented product listing, cart UI, checkout flows.âœ‹ Reused React components for faster development.ðŸ‘Œ Used Axios to call backend REST APIs.ðŸ«± Applied CSS/Styled Components for branding/UI design.

questions.title: Explain Technically faced challenges on your NMG eCommerce Project as a Node JS, Express JS, RESTful API, Microservices, SQL Developer
questions.answer: Yes, I faced some issues while developing Backend Applications. Here main challenges are:â˜ï¸ Challenge 1 â€” Slow product-listing API (high latency)â€¢Main issue: product listing API was slow under load (page loads > 3s).â€¢Why it happened: Unoptimized SQL (full-table scans) + N+1 queries for product images and variants.â€¢How found:Profiling with slow-query logs, EXPLAIN plans, and backend tracing (high DB time).â€¢Fix: Added proper indexes, rewrote queries with joins/CTEs, batch-fetched related data, introduced pagination.â€¢Benefits: Response times dropped significantly, lower DB CPU, better user experience and conversion.âœŒï¸Challenge 2 â€” Inventory race conditions (overselling)â€¢Main issue: Two concurrent checkouts sold the same last SKU.â€¢Why it happened: Lack of transactional control across services and no atomic stock decrement.â€¢How found: Customer complaints + audit logs showed duplicate successful orders for same SKU.â€¢Fix: Implemented DB-level transactions with SELECT ...FOR UPDATE / optimistic locking and moved stock decrement into a single atomic operation; added idempotency keys for order creation.â€¢Benefits: Eliminated overselling, reduced refunds, improved trust and fewer manual fixes.ðŸ¤Ÿ Challenge 3 â€” Inconsistent cache (stale product/pricing data)â€¢Main issue: Users saw old prices after admin updates.â€¢Why it happened: Redis cache TTLs + missing cache invalidation after updates across microservices.â€¢How found: Reproducible steps: update price in Admin â†’ frontend still showed old price; logs showed cache hit.â€¢Fix: Implemented cache invalidation events via message broker (Kafka/Rabbit) and short TTL for critical keys.â€¢Benefits: Data consistency across services, correct pricing during checkout, fewer pricing disputes.

questions.title: Explain Technically faced challenges on your NMG eCommerce Project as a React JS, Redux, CSS, JavaScript, HTML, CSS Developer
questions.answer: Yes, I faced some Challenges while developing frontend Application:â˜ï¸Challenge 1 â€” Slow initial page load / large bundleâ€¢Main issue here is: First-load time high, slow Time-to-Interactive.â€¢Why that issue came means: Large JS bundle (many libs + unused code) and no code-splitting.â€¢How I found issue means: Lighthouse scores, network waterfall showed huge main.js and long parse time. So â€¢I could Fixed this issue â€” steps:1.Audit bundle with webpack source-map-explorer.2.Remove unused libs, replace heavy libs with lighter alternatives.3.Implement route-based code-splitting (React.lazy + Suspense).4.Use dynamic imports for large components (product carousel, admin panels).5.Enable production optimizations: tree-shaking, minification, gzip/Brotli.â€¢Benefits: Faster first paint, improved SEO, higher conversion and Lighthouse scores.âœŒï¸Challenge 2â€”UI state inconsistency (cart & product sync issues)â€¢Main issue: Cart count/UI didnâ€™t reflect backend changes or multiple tabs.â€¢Why: Local component state + stale Redux state + no real-time sync.â€¢How found: Repro on two tabs and after API responses; logs showed stale state updates.â€¢Fix â€” steps:1.Centralize canonical state in Redux (single source of truth).2.Use optimistic updates with rollback on failure.3.Add websocket or polling to sync cart across tabs/sessions.4.Use action idempotency and sequence numbers to avoid out-of-order updates.â€¢Benefits: Consistent UI, fewer checkout errors, better cross-tab UX.ðŸ¤Ÿ Challenge 3â€”Slow rendering / janky UI on product grid (performance)â€¢Main issue: Scrolling grid janks; repaint delays on hover/filters.â€¢Why: Re-rendering many DOM nodes; expensive computations in render.â€¢How found: React Profiler showed frequent re-renders and long commit times.â€¢Fix â€” steps:1.Memoize pure components with React.memo.2.Use useMemo / useCallback for derived data and handlers.3.Virtualize long lists (react-window / react-virtualized).4.Move heavy calculations outside render (precompute or web worker).â€¢Benefits: Smooth scrolling, lower CPU, improved perceived performance.

questions.title: What is HTML?
questions.answer:
HTML is the standard markup language for creating web pages.
It defines the structure and content of a page using elements and tags.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Structure product pages, headings, paragraphs, and lists.
â€¢ Create forms for checkout, login, and search in eCommerce.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ NMG product page uses semantic tags like <article>, <section>, and <header> for SEO and accessibility.
â€¢ Forms for checkout use <form>, proper labels and input types to reduce cart abandonment.

questions.title: What is semantic HTML and why is it important?
questions.answer:
Semantic HTML uses meaningful tags to describe content purpose, not just presentation.
It improves accessibility, SEO, and maintainability.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Use <nav> for navigation, <main> for main content, <footer> for page footer.
â€¢ Screen readers and search engines rely on semantics for better results.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ NMG category pages use <main> and <aside> so filters and content are parsed correctly by crawlers.
â€¢ Semantic markup reduced manual SEO fixes and improved organic product discovery.

questions.title: What does <!DOCTYPE html> do?
questions.answer:
The doctype tells browsers to render the page in standards (HTML5) mode.
It prevents quirks-mode rendering differences across browsers.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Ensure consistent CSS and layout behavior across browsers.
â€¢ Required as the first line of modern HTML documents.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ All NMG pages include the HTML5 doctype to avoid cross-browser layout bugs in product grids.
â€¢ Using the correct doctype reduced UI regressions during browser updates.

questions.title: Difference between block-level and inline elements?
questions.answer:
Block elements start on a new line and take full available width; inline elements flow within a line.
Use blocks for layout and inlines for small content pieces.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Use <div>, <section>, <header> for layout (block).
â€¢ Use <span>, <a>, <strong> for text-level semantics (inline).
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ NMG product cards use block containers for image and meta, inline elements for price and tag labels.
â€¢ Correct usage simplified responsive CSS and reduced layout overrides.

questions.title: How do you make HTML forms accessible?
questions.answer:
Use proper labels, fieldset/legend, ARIA only when necessary, and semantic input types.
Provide clear error messages and keyboard-friendly controls.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Associate <label> with inputs using for/id attributes.
â€¢ Use required, pattern, and type attributes for native validation.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ NMG checkout forms use explicit labels and aria-live regions for validation errors to aid screen readers.
â€¢ Accessible forms lowered support tickets and improved conversion for users with assistive tech.

questions.title: What are some important HTML5 elements you use frequently?
questions.answer:
Key HTML5 elements include <section>, <article>, <nav>, <header>, <footer>, <figure>, and <main>.
They provide meaningful structure and improve document flow and semantics.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Structure content blocks, group media with captions, and declare primary content area.
â€¢ Improve SEO and accessibility via explicit landmarks.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ NMG product detail pages use <figure> with <figcaption> for product images and captions.
â€¢ Search engines and internal crawlers leverage these tags to extract product summaries.

questions.title: How does responsive image loading work (srcset and sizes)?
questions.answer:
Use srcset and sizes to let the browser pick the best image for device resolution and viewport.
This reduces bandwidth and improves load times on mobile.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Provide multiple image widths in srcset and describe expected layout in sizes.
â€¢ Combine with lazy-loading to defer offscreen images.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ NMG serves smaller thumbnails for mobile and larger images for desktop using srcset, improving Core Web Vitals.
â€¢ Reduced mobile data usage led to faster time-to-interactive on category pages.

questions.title: What is the role of meta tags in HTML?
questions.answer:
Meta tags provide metadata like charset, viewport, description, and robots directives.
They affect SEO, mobile rendering, and how pages are indexed or cached.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Set <meta name="viewport"> for responsive scaling.
â€¢ Use description and og: tags to improve social sharing and SEO.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ NMG product pages include structured meta and Open Graph tags to improve link previews and search listings.
â€¢ Proper caching meta and CSP headers reduced click-to-content latency and improved security.

questions.title: When should you use <canvas> vs SVG?
questions.answer:
Use <canvas> for pixel-based, high-performance drawing and animations; use SVG for vector graphics and DOM-accessible shapes.
Choose based on interactivity, scalability, and accessibility needs.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Canvas: complex animations or image processing.
â€¢ SVG: icons, diagrams, and interactive charts that need accessibility.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ NMG uses SVG for scalable icons and simple charts; canvas for image compositing in product customizers.
â€¢ Using SVG improved clarity on high-DPI displays and simplified styling via CSS.

questions.title: How do you optimize HTML for performance and SEO?
questions.answer:
Minimize DOM size, use semantic markup, defer non-critical scripts, and compress assets.
Serve meaningful content early to improve perceived load and SEO signals.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Inline critical CSS, defer JS, and preload key resources.
â€¢ Keep HTML lean and avoid excessive nested elements.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ NMG reduced DOM nodes on category pages and saw measurable improvements in LCP and SEO crawl budget usage.
â€¢ Preloading fonts and hero images improved first meaningful paint on product pages.

questions.title: What are ARIA attributes and when should you use them?
questions.answer:
ARIA provides additional accessibility semantics for complex widgets that native HTML can't express.
Prefer native HTML; use ARIA only when semantics cannot be achieved otherwise.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Use role, aria-label, aria-expanded for custom components.
â€¢ Avoid redundant ARIA on elements that already convey semantics.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ NMG uses ARIA roles on custom widgets like autocomplete and complex filters while keeping native inputs where possible.
â€¢ Proper ARIA usage reduced screen-reader navigation friction during checkout.

questions.title: How do you handle cross-origin and Content Security Policy (CSP) in HTML?
questions.answer:
CSP is a header (or meta) that restricts allowed sources for scripts, styles, and other resources to mitigate XSS.
Use proper CORS headers for API requests and a strict CSP with trusted domains.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Set CSP directives for default-src, script-src, style-src, and img-src.
â€¢ Use crossorigin attributes and Access-Control-Allow-Origin on APIs.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ NMG enforced a strict CSP and configured CORS for CDN and API domains, reducing XSS risk and securing third-party integrations.
â€¢ CSP reporting helped catch accidental inline scripts and tighten security policy over time.

questions.title: What is HTML and why to use it? How It runs in the browser or what will happen when you run the HTML file or page in the Browser?
questions.answer: HTML (HyperText Markup Language) is a standard markup language used to create web pages. It provides the structure and content of web pages using tags and elements. When you run an HTML file in a browser, the browser parses the HTML code and renders it as a visual web page. The browser interprets the HTML tags, applies default styling, and displays the content to the user. HTML works together with CSS for styling and JavaScript for interactivity.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Creating web page structure
â€¢ Displaying content
â€¢ Building web applications
â€¢ Creating forms
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Building websites
â€¢ Creating web interfaces
â€¢ Email templates
â€¢ Document markup

questions.title: What is <!DOCTYPE HTML> ? why to use it? Or keep it in the HTML page? What will happen If you not keep <!DOCTYPE HTML> in the HTML Page?
questions.answer: <!DOCTYPE HTML> is a declaration that specifies the version of HTML being used. It tells the browser to render the page in standards mode. Without <!DOCTYPE>, the browser may enter 'quirks mode', which can cause inconsistent rendering and unexpected behavior. The <!DOCTYPE> should always be the first line in an HTML document. It is required in HTML5 and helps ensure consistent cross-browser compatibility.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Standards compliance
â€¢ Browser compatibility
â€¢ Ensuring proper rendering
â€¢ HTML5 validation
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Creating valid HTML documents
â€¢ Ensuring cross-browser support
â€¢ Web standards compliance
â€¢ HTML validation

questions.title: What are the Block Level Tags and Inline Elements? What are the main differences between them?
questions.answer:
Block-level tags (like
,

,

,
) take up the full available width and start on a new line. They create a line break before and after. Inline elements (like , , , ) only take up as much width as needed and flow within text. Block elements respect all margins and padding, while inline elements only respect left and right margins. Block elements can contain other block and inline elements, but inline elements cannot contain block elements.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Page layout
â€¢ Content organization
â€¢ Styling structure
â€¢ Semantic markup
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Creating page sections
â€¢ Typography management
â€¢ Layout control
â€¢ Content wrapping

questions.title: What is <div> and <span> why to use them?
questions.answer: <div> is a block-level container element used to group and organize content. <span> is an inline container used to wrap small portions of text or inline content. Both are generic elements with no semantic meaning but are useful for applying CSS styles and JavaScript manipulation. <div> is used for larger sections and layout, while <span> is used for small inline text selections. They are the most commonly used container elements in HTML.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Creating layouts
â€¢ Grouping content
â€¢ Applying styles
â€¢ JavaScript manipulation
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Page structure
â€¢ CSS styling
â€¢ Responsive design
â€¢ DOM manipulation

questions.title: What are the Semantic Elements in the HTML? Why to use it? What are the benefits of it?
questions.answer: Semantic elements clearly describe their meaning to both the browser and developer (e.g., <header>, <nav>, <main>, <article>, <section>, <aside>, <footer>). They provide meaning and structure to web content. Benefits include: improved SEO, better accessibility for screen readers, cleaner and more maintainable code, and improved browser compatibility. Semantic HTML helps search engines understand page structure and helps assistive technologies provide better user experience.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ SEO optimization
â€¢ Accessibility
â€¢ Code clarity
â€¢ Document structure
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Building accessible websites
â€¢ Improving search rankings
â€¢ Assistive technology support
â€¢ Content organization

questions.title: What are the Web Workers in the HTML Page? What are the Types of Web Storages in the HTML?
questions.answer: Web Workers are JavaScript programs that run in the background, separate from the main thread. They allow heavy computations to run without blocking the UI. Web Storages are mechanisms to store data on the client-side: LocalStorage (persistent), SessionStorage (temporary per session), and Cookies (small persistent data). Web Storage provides larger storage capacity than cookies and is more efficient for client-side data storage.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Background computation
â€¢ Data persistence
â€¢ Client-side caching
â€¢ Session management
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Image processing
â€¢ Data analytics
â€¢ User preferences
â€¢ Form data caching

questions.title: What is LocalStorage? Why to use it? When to use it? What is the Importance of it?
questions.answer: LocalStorage is a client-side storage mechanism that stores data persistently with no expiration date. Data remains even after the browser is closed. It is limited to about 5-10MB per domain. Use it for: user preferences, app settings, authentication tokens, and data that should persist between sessions. Importance: reduces server load, improves performance, enables offline functionality, and enhances user experience by remembering user preferences.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ User preferences
â€¢ App settings
â€¢ Caching data
â€¢ Authentication tokens
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Remember login state
â€¢ Store user theme preference
â€¢ Save form data
â€¢ Offline app support

questions.title: What is SessionStorage? Why to use it? When to use it? What is the Importance of it?
questions.answer: SessionStorage is similar to LocalStorage but stores data only for the duration of the page session. Data is cleared when the tab or browser is closed. It is useful for temporary data that should not persist. Use it for: temporary user data, form progress, session-specific settings, and navigation state. Importance: provides temporary storage without polluting persistent storage, improves performance by reducing database queries, and enhances security by not persisting sensitive data.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Temporary data
â€¢ Session state
â€¢ Form progress
â€¢ Navigation history
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Multi-step form data
â€¢ Session tokens
â€¢ Temporary UI state
â€¢ Page navigation stack

questions.title: What are the main differences between LocalStorage and Session Storages? Cookies vs Cahes?
questions.answer: LocalStorage persists indefinitely until explicitly cleared, while SessionStorage clears when the tab closes. LocalStorage and SessionStorage have ~5-10MB capacity, while cookies have ~4KB. Cookies are sent with every HTTP request (overhead), while Web Storage is not. LocalStorage/SessionStorage are synchronous and faster, cookies can be HttpOnly for security. Caching is a broader concept including browser cache, CDN cache, and application cache. Choose LocalStorage for persistent user data, SessionStorage for temporary data, and Cookies for small data that needs to be sent to the server.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Data persistence
â€¢ Performance optimization
â€¢ Security
â€¢ Client-server communication
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Authentication
â€¢ User preferences
â€¢ Session management
â€¢ Performance optimization

questions.title: What are the HTML5 Features explain all?
questions.answer: HTML5 major features include: Semantic elements (<header>, <nav>, <article>, etc.), Canvas (drawing graphics), SVG (scalable vector graphics), Audio and Video tags (media playback), Geolocation API (location services), Web Storage (LocalStorage, SessionStorage), Web Workers (background processing), History API (navigation control), Drag and Drop API, Offline capabilities, Responsive design support, improved form validation, and better accessibility. HTML5 modernized web development enabling rich, interactive applications without plugins.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Modern web development
â€¢ Rich media
â€¢ Offline applications
â€¢ Enhanced user experience
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Video streaming
â€¢ Interactive graphics
â€¢ Mobile-first design
â€¢ Progressive web apps

questions.title: What is GeoLocation and why to use it? When to use it? For what purpose we do have to use it?
questions.answer: Geolocation API allows web applications to obtain the user's geographical position with their permission. It uses GPS, cell tower triangulation, or IP address. Why use it: enables location-based services, personalized content, and context-aware features. When to use it: mapping applications, location-based recommendations, local business discovery, weather apps, and ride-sharing services. Always request permission and use HTTPS. Important for privacy - users must explicitly grant permission.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Mapping services
â€¢ Location-based recommendations
â€¢ Local search
â€¢ Proximity alerts
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Google Maps integration
â€¢ Weather apps
â€¢ Restaurant finders
â€¢ Ride-sharing apps

questions.title: What is CSS?
questions.answer:
CSS is Cascading Style Sheets, used to style and layout web pages.
It separates presentation from HTML structure, enabling consistent design across multiple pages.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Apply colors, fonts, spacing, and layout to HTML elements.
â€¢ Create responsive designs that adapt to different screen sizes.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ NMG product pages use CSS for responsive grid layouts that adapt from mobile to desktop views.
â€¢ Global CSS framework ensures consistent branding across all eCommerce pages.

questions.title: What is CSS specificity and how does cascading work?
questions.answer:
Specificity determines which CSS rule applies when multiple rules target the same element.
Cascading means the last rule wins if specificity is equal; inline > IDs > classes/attributes > elements.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Manage conflicts between global styles and component overrides.
â€¢ Use classes and avoid !important to keep styles predictable.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ NMG component library uses low-specificity selectors so product teams can safely override styles without !important.
â€¢ Proper cascade hierarchy reduced CSS bugs and simplified maintenance.

questions.title: Explain the CSS box model.
questions.answer:
The box model consists of content, padding, border, and margin.
Understanding it is essential for layout; box-sizing controls whether width/height includes padding/border.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Predict element sizes and spacing in layouts.
â€¢ Use box-sizing: border-box for easier calculations.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ NMG sets box-sizing: border-box globally so product cards render at exact widths without overflow.
â€¢ Consistent box model reduced layout shifts and improved UI predictability.

questions.title: What is Flexbox and when should you use it?
questions.answer:
Flexbox is a layout model for arranging items in a row or column with automatic spacing and alignment.
Use it for component-level layouts, navigation bars, and card grids.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Distribute space evenly among items using justify-content and align-items.
â€¢ Create flexible, responsive layouts without floats or positioning.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ NMG navigation bar uses flexbox to align items and distribute space dynamically.
â€¢ Checkout form uses flex columns for stacking inputs responsively on mobile.

questions.title: What is CSS Grid and how does it differ from Flexbox?
questions.answer:
CSS Grid is a 2D layout system for complex, multi-row/column layouts.
Flexbox is 1D; Grid is better for page-level layouts with explicit rows and columns.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Create dashboard-like layouts with consistent columns and rows.
â€¢ Combine Grid for overall structure and Flexbox for component internals.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ NMG product listing uses CSS Grid for responsive 3â€“4 column layouts that adapt to viewport width.
â€¢ Admin dashboard uses grid to organize product tables, charts, and sidebar panels.

questions.title: Explain CSS positioning (static, relative, absolute, fixed, sticky).
questions.answer:
CSS positioning controls how elements flow and overlap.
Static (default), Relative (offset in place), Absolute (removed from flow, positioned relative to parent), Fixed (pinned to viewport), Sticky (toggles between relative and fixed).
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Create floating elements, overlays, and sticky headers.
â€¢ Use absolute positioning sparingly; flexbox/grid are often better.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ NMG sticky header stays visible when scrolling product lists.
â€¢ Modal dialogs use fixed positioning to center overlay above page content.

questions.title: How do you build responsive CSS designs?
questions.answer:
Use media queries to apply different styles at breakpoints, mobile-first approach, and relative units (rem, %, vw).
Test on real devices and use flexbox/grid for natural responsiveness.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Define breakpoints (mobile, tablet, desktop) and adjust layout for each.
â€¢ Use flexible images and avoid fixed widths.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ NMG uses mobile-first CSS and media queries to transform single-column mobile layout to multi-column desktop.
â€¢ Responsive hero images adapt from small mobile versions to full-width desktop images.

questions.title: What are CSS pseudo-classes and pseudo-elements?
questions.answer:
Pseudo-classes (:hover, :focus, :nth-child) target elements based on state or position.
Pseudo-elements (::before, ::after, ::first-line) create/style virtual elements.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Add hover effects to buttons and links.
â€¢ Use ::before/::after for decorative elements without extra HTML.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ NMG product buttons use :hover and :focus for interactive feedback.
â€¢ Testimonial quotes use ::before content for decorative quote marks.

questions.title: How do you use CSS custom properties (variables)?
questions.answer:
CSS variables (--name: value) allow reusable values for colors, spacing, and fonts.
Use them in var(--name) and update them globally or per-scope.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Define a color palette and reuse across components.
â€¢ Change theme colors dynamically via JavaScript without recompiling CSS.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ NMG defines --primary-color, --text-color, and reuses them across all components.
â€¢ Dark mode support swaps CSS variables via JS without CSS duplication.

questions.title: What is the difference between CSS transitions and animations?
questions.answer:
Transitions smoothly change properties over time in response to events (hover, click).
Animations use keyframes to define complex, multi-step sequences that play independently.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Use transitions for simple property changes (hover effects, color shifts).
â€¢ Use animations for loading spinners, entrance effects, and complex sequences.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ NMG product image on hover uses a smooth transition for opacity/scale effects.
â€¢ Loading spinner uses @keyframes animation to rotate indefinitely.

questions.title: How do you optimize CSS for performance?
questions.answer:
Minimize CSS, remove unused styles (PurgeCSS), avoid expensive selectors, use will-change sparingly, and defer non-critical CSS.
Critical CSS should inline; non-critical should load async.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Audit CSS with DevTools and remove dead code.
â€¢ Avoid expensive selectors like * or deeply nested rules.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ NMG uses PurgeCSS to strip unused Tailwind classes, reducing CSS bundle from 500KB to 50KB.
â€¢ Inlined critical CSS for hero section improves above-the-fold rendering.

questions.title: What are CSS preprocessors (Sass/Less) and why use them?
questions.answer:
Preprocessors like Sass add variables, nesting, mixins, and functions to CSS.
They compile to standard CSS and improve maintainability, especially for large projects.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Use nesting to reduce code repetition and improve readability.
â€¢ Create reusable mixins for common patterns (buttons, forms).
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ NMG uses Sass mixins for breakpoints and color utilities shared across the design system.
â€¢ Nested rules reduce selector duplication and simplify button/input styling.

questions.title: What is JavaScript?
questions.answer: JavaScript is a high-level, interpreted programming language that runs in browsers and on servers (Node.js). It is used to add interactivity, manipulate the DOM, handle events, and build full-stack applications. It supports dynamic typing, first-class functions, and prototype-based inheritance.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Client-side interactivity
â€¢ Server-side APIs
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Form validation
â€¢ Dynamic product filters

questions.title: What are the features of JavaScript?
questions.answer: Key features: dynamic typing, prototype-based OOP, first-class functions, closures, event-driven, asynchronous programming (Promises, async/await), runs in browser and server environments, and has a rich ecosystem of libraries and frameworks.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Rapid prototyping
â€¢ Event-driven UIs
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Real-time search suggestions
â€¢ Asynchronous API calls

questions.title: What are Data Types in JavaScript?
questions.answer: Primitive types: string, number, bigint, boolean, undefined, null, symbol. Non-primitive: object (including arrays, functions, dates). JavaScript is dynamically typed so variables can hold any type.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Type handling
â€¢ Data validation
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Parsing API responses
â€¢ Form input handling

questions.title: What is the difference between Primitive and Non-Primitive data types?
questions.answer: Primitives are immutable values stored by value (e.g., numbers, strings). Non-primitives (objects/arrays/functions) are stored and assigned by reference; they are mutable and can hold properties.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Memory model
â€¢ Equality checks
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Copying objects carefully to avoid shared mutation

questions.title: What is ECMAScript?
questions.answer: ECMAScript (ES) is the standard specification that defines the JavaScript language. ECMAScript versions (ES5, ES6/ES2015, ES2020, etc.) define language features implemented by engines (V8, SpiderMonkey).
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Language standardization
â€¢ Feature planning
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Using ES modules and modern syntax compiled by Babel

questions.title: What is the difference between JavaScript and ECMAScript?
questions.answer: ECMAScript is the language specification; JavaScript is the implementation (a dialect) in browsers and runtimes. In practice JS implements ECMAScript plus host APIs (DOM, BOM).
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Transpiling ES features to support older browsers

questions.title: What is var, let, const?
questions.answer: `var` declares function-scoped or globally-scoped variables (hoisted). `let` declares block-scoped variables. `const` creates block-scoped read-only bindings (the reference is constant, objects can still be mutated). Prefer `let`/`const` in modern code.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Variable declarations
â€¢ Scoping rules
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Use const for config objects, let for loop counters

questions.title: What are the differences between var vs let vs const?
questions.answer: `var` is function-scoped and hoisted; allows re-declaration. `let` is block-scoped, not re-declarable in same scope, not initialized until declaration (TDZ). `const` is like let but cannot be reassigned; objects are still mutable.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Choosing declarations
â€¢ Avoiding bugs
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Replacing var with let/const to prevent accidental globals

questions.title: What is Hoisting?
questions.answer: Hoisting is JavaScript behavior where declarations (var, function) are moved to top of their scope at runtime. `var` declarations are hoisted and initialized with undefined; `let`/`const` are hoisted but uninitialized (TDZ). Function declarations are hoisted with their definitions.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Avoid relying on hoisting; declare variables before use

questions.title: What is Temporal Dead Zone?
questions.answer: TDZ is the time between entering a scope and the variable's actual declaration when `let`/`const` exist but cannot be accessed; accessing them throws ReferenceError. Prevents use-before-declare for block-scoped variables.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Using let/const safely in loops and blocks

questions.title: What is Scope?
questions.answer: Scope is the region of code where a binding (variable) is visible. JavaScript has global scope, function scope, and block scope (for let/const). Scope controls variable lifetime and access.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Keeping variable usage limited inside modules/components

questions.title: Types of Scope in JavaScript?
questions.answer: Global scope (top-level), function scope (declared with function or var), block scope (let/const within { }). Module scope (ES modules have their own top-level scope).
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Designing modules
â€¢ Avoiding globals
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Using module scope for component-level utilities

questions.title: What is Lexical Scope?
questions.answer: Lexical scope (static scope) means the accessibility of variables is determined by the physical placement of code. Inner functions can access variables from outer lexical scopes. Closures use lexical scoping.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Factory functions that capture configuration values

questions.title: What is Scope Chaining?
questions.answer: Scope chaining is the process JS uses to resolve variable references: it first looks in the current scope, then outer scopes, up to global. This chain creates the lookup path for identifiers.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Understanding why a variable is shadowed by inner scope

questions.title: What is a normal function?
questions.answer: A normal (function declaration or expression) is defined with the `function` keyword and has its own `this` context (dynamic at call time for non-arrow functions) and is hoisted (declaration form). Example: function add(a,b){return a+b}.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Reusable logic
â€¢ Methods on objects
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ API utility functions in services

questions.title: What is an arrow function?
questions.answer: Arrow functions use `=>` syntax and have lexical `this` (they inherit `this` from surrounding scope), cannot be used as constructors, and do not have their own `arguments` object. Example: const add=(a,b)=>a+b.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Short callbacks
â€¢ Lexical this
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Array map/filter callbacks and small render helpers

questions.title: Differences between normal function vs arrow function?
questions.answer: Key differences: arrow functions have lexical `this`, no `arguments`, cannot be used with `new`, and are not hoisted like function declarations. Choose arrow for concise callbacks, normal functions for methods needing dynamic `this`.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Use arrow functions for React component helpers

questions.title: What is a Higher-Order Function?
questions.answer: A higher-order function takes functions as arguments and/or returns a function. Examples: map, filter, reduce, and function factories. Useful for abstraction and composition.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ createLogger middleware that returns a wrapped function

questions.title: What is a Callback Function?
questions.answer: A callback is a function passed to another function to be called later (synchronously or asynchronously). Historically used for async patterns before Promises/async-await.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Async handling
â€¢ Event handlers
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ XHR/fetch .then callbacks or event listeners

questions.title: What is Function Currying?
questions.answer: Currying transforms a function with multiple arguments into a sequence of functions each taking a single argument. Example: f(a,b) -> f(a)(b). Useful for partial application and reusable configuration.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Partial application
â€¢ Reusable factories
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ createEndpoint(baseUrl)(path) to build API callers

questions.title: What is Pure Function?
questions.answer: A pure function returns the same output for the same inputs and has no side effects (doesn't modify external state). Pure functions are easier to test and reason about.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Pure reducers in Redux

questions.title: What is IIFE?
questions.answer: Immediately Invoked Function Expression: a function defined and executed immediately to create a private scope. Syntax: (function(){ /* ... */ })(); Used historically for module-like encapsulation before ES modules.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Legacy scripts wrapping module code

questions.title: What are First-Class Functions?
questions.answer: In JS functions are first-class citizens: they can be assigned to variables, passed to/returned from functions, and have properties. This enables functional programming patterns.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Event handlers stored in variables

questions.title: What is the this keyword?
questions.answer: `this` refers to the execution context's object. Its value depends on how a function is called: method calls set `this` to the receiver object, standalone functions default to global/undefined in strict mode, constructors set `this` to the new instance.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Using methods that access instance properties

questions.title: How does this behave in normal vs arrow functions?
questions.answer: Normal functions have dynamic `this` determined by call site (call/apply/bind can change it). Arrow functions inherit `this` lexically from surrounding scope and cannot change it with call/apply/bind.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Arrow function in class field to preserve `this` in callbacks

questions.title: What is call()?
questions.answer: `call` is a function method that invokes a function with an explicit `this` value and arguments passed individually: fn.call(thisArg, arg1, arg2).
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Method borrowing
â€¢ Setting this
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Using array methods for array-like objects: Array.prototype.slice.call(args)

questions.title: What is apply()?
questions.answer: `apply` is like call but accepts arguments as an array: fn.apply(thisArg, [arg1, arg2]). Useful when arguments are in an array form.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Forwarding args
â€¢ Varargs handling
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Math.max.apply(null, arr) to get max from array

questions.title: What is bind()?
questions.answer: `bind` returns a new function with `this` permanently bound to the provided value and optionally prefills arguments: const f2 = f.bind(thisArg, a).
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Event handlers
â€¢ Partial application
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Binding class methods in older React class components

questions.title: Differences between call, apply, bind?
questions.answer: `call` invokes immediately with args listed; `apply` invokes immediately with args array; `bind` returns a new function bound to provided `this` without invoking immediately.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ API differences
â€¢ Runtime usage
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Using bind to pre-bind context for callbacks

questions.title: What is the difference between == vs ===?
questions.answer: `==` checks for equality with type coercion; `===` checks for strict equality without coercion. Prefer `===` to avoid unexpected conversions.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Equality checks
â€¢ Bug avoidance
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Comparing IDs where types might differ (string vs number) -- use ===

questions.title: What is NaN?
questions.answer: NaN stands for Not-a-Number and is the result of invalid numeric operations (e.g., parseInt("a") or 0/0). It is a special numeric value in IEEE-754.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Checking parse results from API and handling invalid numbers

questions.title: Why is NaN === NaN false?
questions.answer: By specification NaN is not equal to anything, including itself. Use Number.isNaN(value) or isNaN to check for NaN.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Detecting invalid numeric results

questions.title: What is Type Coercion?
questions.answer: Type coercion is the automatic or implicit conversion of values from one type to another (e.g., "5" + 1 -> "51"). Coercion happens in comparisons and arithmetic operations.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Implicit conversions
â€¢ Operator behavior
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Guarding against string concatenation when numeric addition expected

questions.title: What is Implicit Coercion?
questions.answer: Implicit coercion occurs when JS automatically converts types during operations (e.g., == comparison, arithmetic with mixed types). Explicit coercion uses functions like Number(), String().
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Debugging errors
â€¢ Data hygiene
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Parsing query params which are strings into numbers explicitly

questions.title: What is a string in JavaScript?
questions.answer: A string is a sequence of characters used to represent text. In JS strings are immutable and can be created with single, double quotes, or backticks (template literals).
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Product titles and descriptions

questions.title: Ways to create strings?
questions.answer: Using single quotes ('...'), double quotes ("..."), or template literals (backticks) which support interpolation and multi-line strings. Also via String() constructor.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Template literal for constructing URLs with query params

questions.title: Important string methods?
questions.answer: Common methods: length, slice, substring, substr, indexOf, includes, startsWith, endsWith, toLowerCase, toUpperCase, trim, split, replace, match.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Sanitizing user input and search indexing

questions.title: What is string immutability?
questions.answer: Strings are immutable â€” operations return a new string rather than modifying the original. To change a string, assign the result of an operation to a new variable.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Memory considerations
â€¢ Safe transformations
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Transforming product names without mutating input sources

questions.title: What is Template Literal?
questions.answer: Template literals (backticks) allow string interpolation with ${expr}, multi-line strings, and tagged templates for custom processing.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Readable templates
â€¢ Multi-line strings
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Building HTML fragments or URLs with variables

questions.title: What is an array?
questions.answer: An array is an ordered list-like object used to store multiple values accessed by numeric indices. Arrays are objects with array-specific methods.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Product lists, cart items

questions.title: Ways to create arrays?
questions.answer: Literal: [] or new Array(length) or Array.of(...items). Use literals for most cases: const a=[1,2,3].
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Building product arrays from API responses

questions.title: What is map()?
questions.answer: map creates a new array by applying a function to each element of the original array. It does not mutate the original array.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Rendering product cards from product data

questions.title: What is filter()?
questions.answer: filter returns a new array containing elements that satisfy a predicate function. Does not mutate original.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Filtering products by category or price range

questions.title: What is reduce()?
questions.answer: reduce applies a reducer function to accumulate array values into a single result (sum, object, etc.). It receives an accumulator and current value.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Calculating cart totals

questions.title: What is forEach()?
questions.answer: forEach iterates over array elements and calls a provided function for each element; it returns undefined and is used for side effects rather than producing new arrays.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Logging items or mutating external state

questions.title: Differences between map vs filter vs reduce vs forEach?
questions.answer: map -> transforms to a new array; filter -> selects subset; reduce -> aggregates to single value; forEach -> iterates for side effects without returning a new collection.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Use reduce to sum prices, map to render UI components

questions.title: What is Shallow Copy?
questions.answer: A shallow copy duplicates top-level values of an object/array but keeps references to nested objects. e.g., spread operator creates a shallow copy.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Copying product object to change top-level fields while sharing nested references

questions.title: What is Deep Copy?
questions.answer: Deep copy duplicates nested structures recursively so mutations to the copy do not affect the original. Use structuredClone, JSON methods (with caveats), or custom recursive cloning.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Immutable state snapshots for undo/redo

questions.title: Spread operator vs Rest operator?
questions.answer: Spread (...) expands iterables into individual elements (e.g., [...arr]). Rest collects function arguments or remaining properties into an array/object (e.g., function(...args) or const {a,...rest}=obj). Same syntax, different context.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Argument handling
â€¢ Cloning objects
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Merging arrays and extracting remaining props in components

questions.title: Tricky Output Questions on Arrays?
questions.answer: Common tricky outputs involve reference sharing, sparse arrays, mutation during iteration, and pitfalls of comparing arrays. Example: map with index as key in React causing re-rendering issues. Understand shallow copy vs deep copy.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Avoiding mutation bugs when updating nested cart items

questions.title: What is an object in JavaScript?
questions.answer: An object is a collection of key-value pairs; keys are strings or symbols and values can be any type. Objects provide structure for modeling real-world entities.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Product objects with id, title, price

questions.title: Ways to create objects?
questions.answer: Object literal {}, Object.create(proto), constructor functions (new), and class syntax (ES6). Use literals for most cases.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Factory patterns
â€¢ Prototypal inheritance
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Creating product DTOs from API

questions.title: Important object methods?
questions.answer: Object.keys, Object.values, Object.entries, Object.assign, Object.create, Object.freeze, Object.seal, hasOwnProperty, and Object.getPrototypeOf.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Extracting keys for display columns or freezing config objects

questions.title: What is Object Destructuring?
questions.answer: Destructuring extracts properties from objects into variables: const {id, name} = product. Supports defaults, renaming, nested patterns.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Cleaner syntax
â€¢ Parameter unpacking
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Destructuring props in React components

questions.title: What is Optional Chaining?
questions.answer: Optional chaining (?.) allows safe access to nested properties without throwing if intermediate is null/undefined: obj?.a?.b. Useful to avoid runtime errors on missing nested data.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Safe access
â€¢ Defensive coding
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Accessing deep API fields that may be absent

questions.title: What is Prototypal Inheritance?
questions.answer: JavaScript objects can inherit from other objects via prototype chains. Methods defined on prototypes are shared by instances. ES6 classes are syntactic sugar over prototypes.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Shared behavior
â€¢ Memory efficiency
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Defining shared methods on model prototypes

questions.title: What is a Prototype?
questions.answer: A prototype is an object from which other objects inherit properties. Every object has an internal [[Prototype]] (accessible via Object.getPrototypeOf or __proto__).
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Inheritance model
â€¢ Method sharing
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Polyfills attaching methods onto prototypes

questions.title: Tricky Output Questions on Objects?
questions.answer: Tricky cases include property ordering, reference equality, mutating shared nested properties, and enum-like behavior with symbols. Also remember that objects are compared by reference, not by value.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Avoid shallow merges that keep shared nested refs leading to bugs

questions.title: What is DOM?
questions.answer: DOM is the Document Object Model â€” a tree representation of HTML documents that browsers expose as a programmable API to read/modify page structure, content, and styles.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ DOM manipulation
â€¢ Rendering UI
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Updating cart totals and injecting product lists

questions.title: Why do we use DOM?
questions.answer: DOM allows scripts to interact with the page: query elements, change text or attributes, add event listeners, and create dynamic user interfaces.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Dynamically updating product availability without reload

questions.title: Important DOM methods?
questions.answer: document.querySelector, querySelectorAll, getElementById, createElement, appendChild, removeChild, addEventListener, closest, matches, classList methods.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Selecting elements
â€¢ Event handling
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Attaching click handlers for add-to-cart buttons

questions.title: What is Event Bubbling?
questions.answer: Bubbling is when events propagate from the innermost target up through ancestor elements. Use event.stopPropagation() to prevent bubbling.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Click events captured at container to handle many children

questions.title: What is Event Capturing?
questions.answer: Capturing is the opposite phase: events move from document root down to the target. You can register listeners in capture phase by passing {capture:true} to addEventListener.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Setting up global listeners that intercept events before children

questions.title: What is Event Delegation?
questions.answer: Delegate events to a common ancestor and detect the actual target via event.target to handle many children efficiently and avoid many listeners.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Performance
â€¢ Simpler listener management
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Single click listener on product list container for add-to-cart buttons

questions.title: What is BOM?
questions.answer: BOM (Browser Object Model) includes browser-provided objects not part of the DOM like window, navigator, location, history, and screen. These give access to browser-level functionality.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Browser APIs
â€¢ Navigation control
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Reading location.search for query params

questions.title: Types of BOM Objects?
questions.answer: Common objects: window, document (DOM), navigator, location, history, screen, localStorage, sessionStorage, and XMLHttpRequest/ fetch as web APIs.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Browser capabilities
â€¢ State persistence
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Using history.pushState for SPA navigation

questions.title: Important BOM methods?
questions.answer: window.alert, confirm, prompt, location.assign, history.pushState, navigator.geolocation, setTimeout/setInterval, and console APIs.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Using setTimeout to debounce UI updates

questions.title: What is localStorage?
questions.answer: localStorage is a Web Storage API for storing string key-value pairs that persist across sessions for a given origin. Capacity is typically several MBs and data is not sent with requests.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Client persistence
â€¢ Offline data
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Storing last-viewed product or cart draft (careful with sensitive data)

questions.title: What is sessionStorage?
questions.answer: sessionStorage is like localStorage but data lasts only for the page session (tab). It is cleared when the tab/window is closed.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Temporary form drafts per tab

questions.title: What are cookies?
questions.answer: Cookies are small name=value pairs sent with HTTP requests (unless flagged HttpOnly) and used for session tracking. They have size limits and can be configured with attributes (Secure, HttpOnly, SameSite, expires).
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Server-set session cookie after login

questions.title: localStorage vs sessionStorage vs cookies vs cache?
questions.answer: localStorage/sessionStorage: client-side string storage (no automatic server send). Cookies: sent to server, used for auth, limited size. Cache (Cache API): stores responses for offline usage and service workers.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Use cookies for server sessions, localStorage for non-sensitive user prefs

questions.title: Is JavaScript single-threaded or multi-threaded?
questions.answer: JS (in browsers) is mostly single-threaded (main thread). Web Workers provide parallelism for heavy tasks. Event loop and async APIs allow concurrency without multi-threaded shared memory on main thread.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Concurrency model
â€¢ Offloading work
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Using Web Workers for heavy image processing

questions.title: What is synchronous vs asynchronous JavaScript?
questions.answer: Synchronous code runs in sequence blocking the thread. Asynchronous code schedules work (callbacks, Promises, async/await, timers) so the main thread can continue and the work runs later (via event loop micro/macrotasks).
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Responsive UIs
â€¢ Non-blocking IO
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Fetching API data without freezing UI

questions.title: What is the Event Loop?
questions.answer: The event loop is a runtime mechanism that handles the call stack and task queues (macrotasks and microtasks). It picks tasks to execute so async callbacks and promise reactions run after current stack completes.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Async scheduling
â€¢ Concurrency reasoning
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Understanding why setTimeout 0 runs after Promise.then

questions.title: What is the Call Stack?
questions.answer: Call stack is the LIFO stack of function frames currently executing. Synchronous function calls push frames, returns pop them. Long-running sync tasks block the stack and the event loop.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Avoid blocking operations in UI thread

questions.title: What are Microtasks?
questions.answer: Microtasks (Promise callbacks, mutation observer callbacks) run after the current stack but before the next macrotask. They are used for promise resolution (queueMicrotask, Promise.then).
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Promise scheduling
â€¢ Ordering guarantees
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Promise.then executes before setTimeout callbacks

questions.title: What are Macrotasks?
questions.answer: Macrotasks include setTimeout, setInterval, I/O, and UI rendering tasks. The event loop processes one macrotask, then microtasks, then rendering, then next macrotask.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Task scheduling
â€¢ UI updates
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ setTimeout used for deferred UI updates

questions.title: What is Promise?
questions.answer: A Promise is an object representing eventual completion/failure of an async operation. It has states: pending, fulfilled, rejected. Use then/catch/finally or async/await for handling.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Async control flow
â€¢ Error handling
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Fetching product data with axios returning a Promise

questions.title: What is Promise Chaining?
questions.answer: Promise chaining links multiple then handlers to perform sequential async operations where each step returns a Promise. Return values pass to next then; errors propagate to catch.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Fetch product -> fetch inventory -> update UI

questions.title: What is async/await?
questions.answer: async/await syntax lets you write asynchronous code that looks synchronous. `async` marks a function that returns a Promise; `await` pauses until a Promise resolves (inside async), simplifying control flow and error handling with try/catch.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Cleaner async code
â€¢ Sequential async operations
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Simpler API calls in service functions

questions.title: What is Callback Hell?
questions.answer: Callback hell refers to deeply nested callbacks that are hard to read and maintain. Promises and async/await mitigate this by flattening async control flow.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Refactor nested XHR callbacks to async/await

questions.title: What is setTimeout()?
questions.answer: setTimeout schedules a function to run after a given delay (ms) and is a macrotask. It returns a timeout id which can be cleared with clearTimeout.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Delay showing a tooltip or retrying an API call

questions.title: What is setInterval()?
questions.answer: setInterval repeatedly runs a function at specified intervals. Use clearInterval to stop it. Be cautious to avoid overlapping executions and memory leaks.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Polling inventory updates (prefer webhooks or SSE if possible)

questions.title: What is Debouncing?
questions.answer: Debouncing groups rapid calls into a single one after a pause: only the last call executes after delay. Useful for input events (search) to reduce frequency of expensive ops.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Debounce search input to reduce API calls

questions.title: What is Throttling?
questions.answer: Throttling ensures a function runs at most once in a specified time window. Useful for scroll/resize handlers to limit execution rate.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Rate control
â€¢ Optimizing handlers
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Throttle scroll handlers to update visible items

questions.title: Difference between Debouncing vs Throttling?
questions.answer: Debounce waits until events stop for a delay; throttle enforces a max call rate. Debounce suits finalizing input; throttle suits periodic updates during continuous events.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Debounce search, throttle scroll

questions.title: What are Memory Leaks?
questions.answer: Memory leaks occur when references to unused objects persist, preventing GC from reclaiming memory. Common causes: event listeners not removed, closures holding large structures, forgotten timers, global caches.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Remove event listeners in component cleanup to prevent leaks

questions.title: How to detect and fix Memory Leaks?
questions.answer: Use browser DevTools memory snapshots/heap profiler, look for retained nodes, remove unused listeners, clear timers, null out large references, and avoid global caches. Use Lighthouse and long-running monitoring.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Profiling a page with increasing memory over time

questions.title: What is Garbage Collection?
questions.answer: GC automatically reclaims memory for unreachable objects. Modern engines use mark-and-sweep algorithms to find reachable objects from roots and free the rest.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Rely on GC but avoid retaining references unnecessarily

questions.title: What is Event Loop Starvation?
questions.answer: Starvation happens when long-running synchronous tasks block the event loop, preventing async callbacks and rendering from running, causing UI freezes. Break work into smaller chunks or use workers.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Offload heavy processing to Web Workers

questions.title: What is XSS (Cross-Site Scripting)?
questions.answer: XSS occurs when attackers inject malicious scripts into pages that execute in other users' browsers. Prevent it by sanitizing user input, escaping output, using CSP, and HttpOnly cookies.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Escape user-generated reviews before inserting into DOM

questions.title: What is CSRF (Cross-Site Request Forgery)?
questions.answer: CSRF tricks authenticated users into making unwanted requests. Mitigate with anti-CSRF tokens, SameSite cookies, and verifying origin/referer headers.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Request validation
â€¢ Auth security
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Include CSRF tokens in state-changing form submissions

questions.title: XSS vs CSRF differences?
questions.answer: XSS injects scripts into pages to run in victim's browser; CSRF forges legitimate requests from the victim to the server. XSS compromises client-side code; CSRF abuses authenticated sessions.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Use CSP and CSRF tokens together for layered defense

questions.title: What is CORS?
questions.answer: Cross-Origin Resource Sharing is a browser mechanism that restricts cross-origin requests unless the server sends appropriate Access-Control-Allow-* headers. Configure server to allow authorized origins or use proxies.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ API security
â€¢ Cross-origin requests
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Enable CORS for API domain from frontend origin in staging

questions.title: What is Content Security Policy?
questions.answer: CSP is an HTTP header that restricts sources for scripts, styles, and other resources to mitigate XSS by whitelisting trusted origins and disallowing inline scripts.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Set CSP to only allow scripts from self and trusted CDNs

questions.title: What is a Service Worker?
questions.answer: A service worker is a script that runs in the background, separate from web pages, enabling offline caching, background sync, and push notifications. It intercepts network requests via the Cache API.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Offline support
â€¢ Background sync
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Cache assets for PWA offline product browsing

questions.title: Service Worker Life Cycle?
questions.answer: Phases: registration -> installation (install event) -> activation (activate event) -> fetch events. Update flow includes skipWaiting and clients.claim to control activation timing.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Updating cached assets gracefully on new deploys

questions.title: What are caching strategies?
questions.answer: Common strategies: Cache First, Network First, Stale-While-Revalidate, Cache Only, Network Only. Choose based on freshness and availability needs.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Cache-first for static assets, network-first for dynamic API data with fallback

questions.title: What is PWA?
questions.answer: Progressive Web App is a web application that uses modern APIs (service workers, manifest) to provide app-like experience â€” installable, offline-capable, and responsive.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Make product catalog available offline with service worker caching

questions.title: How does offline caching work?
questions.answer: Service workers intercept fetch events and serve responses from Cache API when offline; use caching strategies and versioning to update caches.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Offline mode
â€¢ Fast loads
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Show cached product pages when network unavailable

questions.title: What are Closures?
questions.answer: A closure is a function that captures variables from its lexical scope, allowing the function to access those variables even after the outer function has returned.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ createCounter() that returns increment function with private count variable

questions.title: Real-time use cases of Closures?
questions.answer: Use cases: factory functions, memoization, event callbacks that remember context, managing private per-instance state in functional patterns.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Per-component memoized handlers retaining props

questions.title: What is Module Pattern?
questions.answer: Module pattern organizes code into self-contained units (IIFE or ES modules) exposing public API while keeping private internals. ES Modules are modern replacement for older patterns.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Component utility modules exported as named functions

questions.title: What is WeakMap & WeakSet?
questions.answer: WeakMap/WeakSet hold weak references to keys (objects) allowing GC if no other refs exist. Keys must be objects; useful for associating metadata without preventing GC.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Storing metadata for DOM nodes without preventing their collection

questions.title: What is Symbol?
questions.answer: Symbol is a primitive for unique identifiers, often used as non-enumerable object property keys or to define custom behavior (well-known symbols).
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Using Symbol.toStringTag for custom object tagging

questions.title: What is Event Loop Microtask Queue?
questions.answer: Microtask queue holds microtasks (Promise jobs, queueMicrotask) executed after current task and before the next macrotask and rendering; ensures promise continuations run quickly.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Task ordering
â€¢ Promise behavior
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Ensuring .then handlers run before setTimeout callbacks

questions.title: What is Shadow DOM?
questions.answer: Shadow DOM provides encapsulated DOM and styles for web components, preventing style leakage and enabling component-level scoping.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Custom UI elements with isolated styles

questions.title: What is Virtual DOM?
questions.answer: Virtual DOM is an in-memory representation of UI used by frameworks (React) to compute diffs and apply minimal updates to real DOM for performance.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Efficient updates
â€¢ Framework internals
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ React using Virtual DOM to batch updates

questions.title: What is Execution Context?
questions.answer: Execution context is the environment in which JavaScript code is evaluated (variable object, scope chain, this). Global, function, and eval contexts exist. Each function call creates a new execution context.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Understanding variable lifetimes and closures

questions.title: What is Lexical Environment?
questions.answer: Lexical environment is a structure that holds identifier-variable mapping and a reference to outer environment; it models scope and is used to resolve variable lookups.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Debugging variable resolution issues

questions.title: What is the difference between function declaration vs function expression?
questions.answer: Function declarations (function f(){}) are hoisted with their definitions; function expressions (const f = function(){}) are not hoisted and behave like variables (TDZ for let/const). Choose declaration for named, hoisted functions.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Hoisting behavior
â€¢ API design
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Use declarations for utility functions used before definition

questions.title: What are Generators?
questions.answer: Generators (function*) produce iterators and can pause execution with yield. Useful for lazy sequences and advanced async patterns (co), though async/await is usually preferred.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Custom paginated data iterator

questions.title: What are Observables?
questions.answer: Observables (RxJS) represent streams of values over time and provide rich operators for composition. They are not native to JS but widely used in reactive programming.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Reactive streams
â€¢ Event composition
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Streaming search suggestions and debounced inputs

questions.title: What is Memoization?
questions.answer: Memoization caches function results for given inputs to avoid recomputation. Implement via closures or libraries. Useful for expensive pure functions.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Memoize derived product lists or price calculations

questions.title: Tricky Output-Based Questions: hoisting
questions.answer: Output questions on hoisting often show var hoisting (undefined vs ReferenceError for let/const) and function declaration hoisting. Understand initialization vs declaration to reason about outputs.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Explain console logs under hoisting scenarios

questions.title: Tricky Output-Based Questions: this
questions.answer: This tricky outputs include method calls vs detached function calls, arrow functions capturing lexical this, and bind/call/apply effects. Use call site to reason about this value.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Explain output when extracting methods as callbacks

questions.title: Tricky Output-Based Questions: closures
questions.answer: Closures tricky outputs often involve loop variables captured by closures; use let to fix or create IIFE to capture current value. Understand captured references vs values.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Loop callback capture issues with var

questions.title: Tricky Output-Based Questions: promises
questions.answer: Promised-based outputs often test microtask ordering: Promise.then runs before setTimeout. Also test error propagation and returned promises inside then handlers.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Order of async logs with promises and timers

questions.title: Tricky Output-Based Questions: async/await
questions.answer: Async/await outputs test error handling with try/catch, awaiting non-promise values, and how async functions always return promises.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Explain behavior of awaited non-Promise values

questions.title: Tricky Output-Based Questions: arrays & objects
questions.answer: Tricky outputs include reference sharing, mutation, and equality by reference. Also prototype property shadowing and enumeration order edge cases.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Avoiding mutation-related bugs in state updates

questions.title: What is the difference between var, let, and const in JavaScript?
questions.answer: var is function-scoped and hoisted with undefined; let is block-scoped and not hoisted (TDZ); const is block-scoped, not hoisted (TDZ), and cannot be reassigned.

questions.title: What are the drawbacks of using var?
questions.answer: Drawbacks: function scope (confusing), hoisting issues, can be redeclared in same scope, pollutes global namespace, and causes unexpected behaviors.

questions.title: What is block scope and how does let/const provide it?
questions.answer: Block scope limits variable accessibility to a block ({}). let and const create block-scoped bindings inside if, for, while, functions, etc., preventing access outside the block.

questions.title: What is Temporal Dead Zone (TDZ) in JavaScript?
questions.answer: TDZ is the time between entering a scope and when let/const binding is initialized. Accessing the variable throws ReferenceError during TDZ.

questions.title: Why is let/const not hoisted like var?
questions.answer: let/const are hoisted but not initialized (TDZ state), preventing access before declaration. This enforces safer patterns than var's hoisting-to-undefined behavior.

questions.title: What happens when we redeclare variables using var vs let/const?
questions.answer: var allows redeclaration in same scope; let/const throw SyntaxError if redeclared in the same block scope, preventing accidental overwrites.

questions.title: What is hoisting in JavaScript?
questions.answer: Hoisting moves declarations to the top of their scope. var and function declarations are hoisted; function expressions and let/const are not initialized until declaration line.

questions.title: How variables and functions behave during hoisting?
questions.answer: Function declarations are fully hoisted with body; var declarations are hoisted and initialized as undefined; let/const are hoisted but uninitialized (TDZ).

questions.title: Why let/const variables cannot be accessed before initialization?
questions.answer: let/const remain in TDZ from scope entry until the declaration line, preventing accidental use of undefined values like var allows.

questions.title: What are arrow functions in ES6?
questions.answer: Arrow functions use => syntax, have lexical this (no own this), no arguments object, cannot be constructors, and provide concise function syntax.

questions.title: Differences between arrow functions and normal functions?
questions.answer: Arrow: lexical this, no arguments, not hoisted, cannot use new; Normal: dynamic this, has arguments, function declarations hoisted, usable as constructors.

questions.title: Why arrow functions do not have their own this?
questions.answer: Arrow functions inherit this from surrounding lexical scope (parent function/object) rather than getting dynamic this from call site.

questions.title: When should we not use arrow functions?
questions.answer: Avoid arrow functions for: constructors, methods needing dynamic this, callbacks with arguments object, or functions that should be hoisted.

questions.title: What are template literals in ES6?
questions.answer: Template literals use backticks (`) for multi-line strings and ${expression} interpolation, replacing string concatenation for better readability.

questions.title: What is string interpolation?
questions.answer: String interpolation embeds expressions inside template literals using ${} syntax; expressions are evaluated and converted to strings automatically.

questions.title: What are tagged template literals?
questions.answer: Tagged templates call a function with template literal parts and substitutions: function`template${expr}` allows custom processing of template strings.

questions.title: What are default parameters in JavaScript?
questions.answer: Default parameters provide fallback values for function arguments if not supplied: function(a=10) {}. Works with destructuring and expressions.

questions.title: How default parameters work with destructuring?
questions.answer: Default parameters work with destructured parameters: function({a=5, b=10}={}) {}. Inner defaults apply to missing destructured properties.

questions.title: What is array destructuring?
questions.answer: Array destructuring extracts array elements into variables: const [a, b, c] = arr; supports skipping, rest operator, and defaults.

questions.title: What is object destructuring?
questions.answer: Object destructuring extracts object properties into variables: const {name, age} = obj; supports renaming, defaults, nested patterns, and rest.

questions.title: What is nested destructuring?
questions.answer: Nested destructuring extracts values from nested structures: const {user: {name, address: {city}}} = data; works for mixed arrays/objects.

questions.title: What is rest destructuring?
questions.answer: Rest destructuring collects remaining elements: const [a, ...rest] = arr; or const {x, ...props} = obj. Useful for extracting unwanted props.

questions.title: What is the rest operator (...) in JavaScript?
questions.answer: Rest operator collects multiple elements into an array (in parameters) or properties into an object (in destructuring): function(...args), [a, ...rest].

questions.title: What is the spread operator (...) in JavaScript?
questions.answer: Spread operator expands iterables/objects into individual elements: [...arr], {...obj}, func(...args). Used for cloning, merging, and passing arguments.

questions.title: Difference between rest and spread operators?
questions.answer: Rest collects multiple values into a single variable (parameters, destructuring). Spread expands a single iterable into multiple values (function calls, arrays, objects).

questions.title: How to merge arrays using spread operator?
questions.answer: Merge arrays: const merged = [...arr1, ...arr2]; or concat. Spread creates a new array without mutating originals.

questions.title: How to clone objects using spread operator?
questions.answer: Clone objects: const copy = {...original}; creates shallow copy. For deep copy use JSON methods or libraries like lodash.

questions.title: What are ES6 modules?
questions.answer: ES6 modules are reusable code blocks with their own scope using import/export. Each module is isolated and explicitly declares dependencies.

questions.title: What is named export vs default export?
questions.answer: Named export: export const fn = (){} imported via import {fn}; Default export: export default fn; imported via import fn;. A module has one default, many named.

questions.title: What is re-exporting in ES6?
questions.answer: re-exporting makes imported items available for other modules: export {x, y} from "./module"; or export {default} from "./module";

questions.title: What are dynamic imports?
questions.answer: Dynamic imports load modules at runtime: import("./module").then(m => {}); or with await. Useful for code splitting and conditional loading.

questions.title: What is a closure in JavaScript?
questions.answer: A closure is a function that remembers variables from its lexical scope after the outer function returns, enabling private state and encapsulation.

questions.title: How closures work internally?
questions.answer: Closures work via scope chain and lexical environment: when a function is created, it retains references to outer variables. Scopes form a chain for variable lookup.

questions.title: What are the use cases of closures?
questions.answer: Use cases: data privacy, factory functions, event handlers retaining context, memoization, partial application, and module patterns.

questions.title: What are closure-related memory leaks?
questions.answer: Closures unintentionally retain large outer objects preventing GC. Fix by nullifying references, using WeakMap, or restructuring to avoid capturing unnecessary objects.
