When you change the DOM directly the browser performs layout, paint, and compositing which can be expensive for many updates. React minimizes work on the real DOM by computing changes in the Virtual DOM and applying only minimal updates.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Final updates to the browser after virtual diffing

questions.title: What is JSX?
questions.answer: JSX is a syntax extension for JavaScript that looks like HTML and describes UI structure; under the hood it is transformed to React.createElement calls or similar by a compiler (Babel). It is optional but commonly used for readability and declarative UI.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Component templates in product pages

questions.title: How JSX works?
questions.answer: JSX expressions are transpiled to JavaScript calls (e.g., React.createElement) which create React elements (virtual nodes). The transpiler also handles attributes and children conversions into JavaScript objects that React can reconciliate.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Writing product card components

questions.title: Why JSX does not work directly in browsers?
questions.answer: Browsers do not understand JSX syntax; it must be transformed to plain JavaScript (React.createElement calls or compiled functions) by tools like Babel or TypeScript before the bundle runs in the browser.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Dev builds with Babel/TS compiling JSX to JS

questions.title: What is Babel and why to use it?
questions.answer: Babel is a JavaScript compiler that transforms modern JS/JSX/TypeScript syntax into browser-compatible JavaScript. Use it to enable JSX, ES modules, and modern language features in older browsers or build pipelines.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Compiling JSX and modern ES features for production bundles

questions.title: What is Webpack? Why use it?
questions.answer: Webpack is a module bundler that processes JS/CSS/assets and produces optimized bundles. It handles code splitting, loaders, plugins, and can optimize assets for production.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Creating optimized production bundles with code-splitting for product pages

questions.title: How to configure webpack.config.js?
questions.answer: A basic webpack.config defines entry, output, module.rules (loaders for JS/CSS/images), plugins (HTML, DefinePlugin), and optimization (splitChunks). For React apps use Babel loader for JSX and configure dev/prod modes.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Customizing build for server-side rendering or vendor splitting

questions.title: What is Functional Component?
questions.answer: A functional component is a JavaScript function that returns React elements. With Hooks, functional components can hold state and side effects, replacing most class components.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Presentational product cards implemented as functional components

questions.title: Why to use Functional Components over Class Components?
questions.answer: Functional components are simpler, avoid this binding, enable Hooks for state/effects, and generally lead to less boilerplate and clearer logic composition.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Refactoring legacy class components to hooks-based functional components

questions.title: What are benefits of Functional Components?
questions.answer: Less boilerplate, easier testing, Hooks for reusable logic, better composition, and often smaller bundles. They also allow Compiler/runtime optimizations.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Reusable hooks across product pages

questions.title: Real-time use cases of Functional Components in eCommerce project.
questions.answer: ProductCard, FilterBar, CheckoutStep components â€” all can be functional components using Hooks for local state and effects.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Product list, cart item, filter controls

questions.title: What is Class Component?
questions.answer: A class component is a React component defined with ES6 classes extending React.Component; it supports lifecycle methods and state via this.state. Before Hooks, classes were required for stateful logic.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Older admin panels or libraries using class-based components

questions.title: When to use Class Components instead of Functional Components?
questions.answer: Today there are few reasons â€” mostly migrating legacy code or using libraries that require class lifecycles; otherwise prefer functional components with Hooks.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Maintaining legacy components until refactor

questions.title: What are benefits of Class Components?
questions.answer: Stable lifecycle method structure and familiarity in older codebases; some third-party libraries historically required class lifecycle hooks.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Compatibility with older component libraries

questions.title: Real-time eCommerce use cases of Class Components.
questions.answer: Legacy dashboard widgets or third-party integrations not yet migrated to Hooks.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Old admin widgets in maintenance mode

questions.title: Difference between Controlled and Uncontrolled Components.
questions.answer: Controlled components have their value controlled by React state (value + onChange). Uncontrolled components rely on DOM refs for current value. Controlled offers predictability; uncontrolled can be simpler for simple forms.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Cart quantity inputs (controlled) vs file inputs (uncontrolled)

questions.title: When to use Controlled and Uncontrolled Components?
questions.answer: Use controlled when you need validation, immediate UI sync, or complex form interactions. Use uncontrolled for simple, infrequently-read inputs to reduce re-renders.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Checkout forms use controlled inputs for validation

questions.title: What is State in React?
questions.answer: State is internal data managed by a component (via useState/useReducer or this.state) that influences its rendering. State changes trigger re-renders.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Cart item counts stored in state

questions.title: What is Props in React?
questions.answer: Props are read-only inputs passed from parent to child components. They allow data flow down the component tree and make components reusable.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Product details passed to ProductCard as props

questions.title: Difference between State and Props.
questions.answer: Props are external and immutable for the child; state is internal and mutable via setState/useState. Props come from parents; state is managed by the component.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Parent passes product data via props; card manages local UI state

questions.title: What is State Lifting?
questions.answer: Lifting state means moving shared state up to the nearest common ancestor so multiple components can access and modify the same data via props.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Lifting selected filters state to a parent that renders product list and filter summary

questions.title: What is Props Drilling?
questions.answer: Props drilling is passing props through intermediate components that don't need them just to reach a deeply nested component. It becomes unwieldy when many levels are involved.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Passing user token many levels down to a deep modal component

questions.title: What is the issue with Props Drilling?
questions.answer: It makes components tightly coupled, harder to refactor, and increases boilerplate for passing values through many levels.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Difficulty refactoring header->nav->submenu data flows

questions.title: How to solve Props Drilling?
questions.answer: Use Context API, global state (Redux/Zustand), or component composition to avoid passing props through irrelevant intermediates.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Use Context for auth info rather than drilling through many components

questions.title: What is React.createElement?
questions.answer: React.createElement is the function that creates React elements (virtual nodes). JSX compiles to calls to React.createElement (or equivalent) which produce the object React uses for reconciliation.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Understanding JSX compilation when debugging render issues

questions.title: Difference between Component and React.createElement.
questions.answer: A Component is a function/class that returns elements; React.createElement constructs element objects. Components are user-defined; createElement is the primitive used by React to represent UI nodes.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Debugging element trees in devtools

questions.title: What is Pure Component in React?
questions.answer: A PureComponent is a class that implements shouldComponentUpdate with a shallow props/state comparison; in functional code you can use React.memo for similar behavior. It avoids unnecessary re-renders for pure props.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Memoizing product list items that receive immutable props

questions.title: What problem Pure Component solves?
questions.answer: It reduces unnecessary re-renders by skipping updates when props/state did not change shallowly, improving performance for expensive renders.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Large product grids where many items don't change

questions.title: When to use Pure Component?
questions.answer: When component renders are expensive and props are mostly immutable/primitives; measure with profiler first.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Memoize header icons or product tiles

questions.title: Real-time eCommerce use cases of Pure Component.
questions.answer: ProductCard and Category tiles benefit from memoization to avoid re-render when unrelated items update.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Memoized product tiles in long lists

questions.title: What is Higher Order Component?
questions.answer: HOC is a function that takes a component and returns a new component with added behavior (e.g., withAuth, withLoading). Before Hooks, HOCs were common for logic reuse.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ withAuth HOC to guard routes in older code

questions.title: What problem HOC solves?
questions.answer: HOCs abstract repeated logic (data fetching, subscriptions) and inject props or behavior into wrapped components.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Logging, analytics or permission checks added via HOCs

questions.title: When to use HOC?
questions.answer: HOCs are useful when needing to reuse behavior across many components; today custom Hooks or component composition are often preferred.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Legacy wrappers adding feature flags to components

questions.title: Real-time eCommerce use cases of HOC.
questions.answer: Wrapping pages with analytics or A/B experiment logic via HOC; or adding auth gating in admin sections.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ withExperiment HOC for feature flags

questions.title: What is Controlled Component?
questions.answer: A controlled component has its value driven by React state, with an onChange handler updating state; the component value is single-source-of-truth in React.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Checkout inputs with live validation

questions.title: Why to use Controlled Component?
questions.answer: Controlled components allow immediate validation, easier testing, and predictable values across the app.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Ensuring coupon codes validate as user types

questions.title: Real-time use cases of Controlled Component in eCommerce.
questions.answer: Checkout form fields, address auto-complete, quantity inputs requiring validation and sync.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Live validation of card number and CVV

questions.title: What is Uncontrolled Component?
questions.answer: Uncontrolled components rely on DOM nodes to manage values (refs) instead of React state; useful for non-critical inputs or third-party integrations.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ File uploads handled via native input refs

questions.title: Why to use Uncontrolled Component?
questions.answer: They can reduce re-renders and be simpler when you don't need live value updates in React state.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Large forms where only final submit is needed

questions.title: Real-time eCommerce use cases of Uncontrolled Component.
questions.answer: File inputs for product images in admin tools or integrations where immediate validation is not necessary.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Image upload forms in seller portal

questions.title: How useEffect works internally?
questions.answer: React schedules effects to run after painting; effects are tracked with their dependency lists and run only when dependencies change. Cleanup functions run before the next effect or on unmount. React batches state updates and may optimize effect invocation timing.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Implementing safe subscriptions and cancellations in product polling

questions.title: Which is good axios or fetch and why?
questions.answer: Axios offers convenience: automatic JSON transforms, interceptors, timeouts, and cancelation helpers. Fetch is built-in and minimal. For production apps with auth/token flows, Axios often simplifies implementation; for tiny scripts, fetch is fine.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ NMG uses Axios for interceptors and token refresh

questions.title: What is useContext?
questions.answer: useContext is a Hook to access the nearest Provider's value for a Context object. It simplifies consuming context without render props or Consumers.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Accessing current user or theme in header components

questions.title: Why use useContext?
questions.answer: It avoids prop drilling for values that many components need (like auth, theme) and keeps code concise.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ User info in nav and account areas

questions.title: How useContext works internally?
questions.answer: useContext reads the current context value from React's context registry associated with the rendering tree; when the Provider value changes, React re-renders consumers.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Understanding performance implications when provider value changes frequently

questions.title: Real-time eCommerce use cases of useContext.
questions.answer: User auth state, theme, currency and language contexts shared across many components.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ CurrencyContext to format prices across product pages

questions.title: Principles of Redux architecture.
questions.answer: Single source of truth (store), state is read-only (actions), changes via pure reducers, predictable state transitions, and optional middleware for side-effects.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Cart and product store with actions and reducers

questions.title: Lifecycle components of Redux.
questions.answer: Typical lifecycle: dispatch action -> middleware intercept (optional) -> reducer updates store -> subscribers (components) re-render. Async flows often use thunks/sagas for side effects.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Order placement flow with middleware for API calls

questions.title: Redux architecture flow end-to-end.
questions.answer: User triggers UI action -> component dispatches an action -> middleware handles async (if any) -> reducer produces new state -> store notifies subscribers -> UI updates. Persist and hydration may exist for caching.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Cart add-to-cart triggers API and updates UI

questions.title: Redux architecture internal life cycle.
questions.answer: Internally Redux reduces by invoking reducers with current state and action, creates new state objects (immutably), and notifies subscribers. Middleware wraps dispatch to add behaviors like logging or async handling.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Custom middleware for analytics on actions

questions.title: What are Middlewares in Redux?
questions.answer: Middlewares are functions that wrap dispatch to intercept actions for logging, async control, routing, or error handling (e.g., thunk, saga, logger). They enhance dispatch behavior.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Auth token refresh implemented as middleware

questions.title: Types of Middlewares in Redux.
questions.answer: Common types: thunk (function-based), saga (generator-based), logger, promise middleware, and custom middlewares for analytics or batching.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Thunk for simple async, saga for complex flows like payments

questions.title: Which one is good Thunk or Saga and why?
questions.answer: Thunk is simpler and good for straightforward async flows. Saga provides more control (cancel, retry, complex orchestration) but has higher complexity. Choose Thunk for most use-cases; adopt Saga for complex, long-running side effects.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Thunk for product fetch; Saga for payment flow orchestration

questions.title: What is Redux?
questions.answer: Redux is a predictable state container for JavaScript apps that centralizes application state in a single store and enforces unidirectional data flow.

questions.title: Why to use Redux?
questions.answer: Use Redux to manage complex app state across many components, enable time-travel debugging, centralize logic, and make state changes predictable and testable.

questions.title: When to use Redux in a project?
questions.answer: Use Redux when app state is shared by many components, when state changes are complex, or when you need predictable state transitions and tooling like DevTools.

questions.title: What problem does Redux solve?
questions.answer: Redux solves state management complexity by providing a single source of truth, explicit update patterns via actions/reducers, and easier debugging.

questions.title: What are the core principles of Redux?
questions.answer: Core principles: single source of truth (one store), state is read-only (changes via actions), and changes are made with pure reducers.

questions.title: What are the Components (parts) of Redux Architecture?
questions.answer: Components: Store (holds state), Actions (descriptions of changes), Reducers (pure functions to update state), Middleware (side-effect handling), and View layer (subscribes to store).

questions.title: What is a Store in Redux?
questions.answer: Store holds the application state tree, provides getState(), dispatch(action), and subscribe(listener). It is created with reducers and enhancers.

questions.title: What is an Action in Redux?
questions.answer: Action is a plain object describing an intention to change state, usually with a `type` field and optional payload.

questions.title: What is a Reducer in Redux?
questions.answer: Reducer is a pure function (state, action) => newState that determines how state changes in response to actions.

questions.title: What is a Root Reducer?
questions.answer: Root reducer combines multiple slice reducers (via combineReducers) into a single reducer for the store.

questions.title: What is the Global State in Redux?
questions.answer: Global state is the single source of truth in Redux: the state tree stored in the store that all parts of the app can access.

questions.title: How Redux updates the state internally?
questions.answer: Redux updates state by dispatching actions; middleware can intercept actions; reducers compute the next state immutably; the store notifies subscribers.

questions.title: What is the flow of Redux Architecture?
questions.answer: Flow: View dispatches action -> Middleware (optional) intercepts -> Action reaches Reducer -> Reducer returns new state -> Store updates -> View re-renders from new state.

questions.title: Explain step-by-step how Redux works internally.
questions.answer: Step-by-step: 1) create store with root reducer; 2) component dispatches action; 3) middleware can handle side-effects; 4) reducer computes next state; 5) store updates and notifies subscribers; 6) UI reads new state and updates.

questions.title: How to implement Redux in React JS step-by-step?
questions.answer: Implement Redux in React: install redux & react-redux, create reducers and rootReducer, create store (optionally with middleware), wrap App with <Provider store={store}>, use useSelector/useDispatch or connect() to access state and dispatch actions.

questions.title: What is the difference between Redux and Context API?
questions.answer: Context is for passing data through component tree; Redux is a full state management solution with predictable updates, middleware, and devtools. Context is simpler for light use-cases; Redux better for complex state logic.

questions.title: What is the difference between Redux and Redux Toolkit?
questions.answer: Redux Toolkit (RTK) is the official, opinionated set of utilities to simplify Redux: reduces boilerplate, provides createSlice, configureStore, and includes best-practices like Immer and DevTools by default.

questions.title: What are the advantages of using Redux?
questions.answer: Advantages: predictable state updates, central store, easier debugging/time-travel, middleware ecosystem, testability, and separation of concerns.

questions.title: What are the disadvantages of Redux?
questions.answer: Disadvantages: boilerplate (mitigated by RTK), added complexity for small apps, learning curve, possible overuse for simple state needs.

questions.title: What is connect() in Redux?
questions.answer: connect() is a HOC from react-redux that maps state and dispatch to component props (older API); newer apps prefer hooks (useSelector/useDispatch).

questions.title: What is useSelector() in Redux?
questions.answer: useSelector(selector) is a hook to read values from the Redux store and subscribe the component to updates of that selected value.

questions.title: What is useDispatch() in Redux?
questions.answer: useDispatch() returns the store's dispatch function so components can dispatch actions.

questions.title: What is store.getState()?
questions.answer: store.getState() returns the current state tree held by the Redux store.

questions.title: What is store.subscribe()?
questions.answer: store.subscribe(listener) registers a callback to be invoked whenever the state changes; returns an unsubscribe function.

questions.title: How to fetch updated state from Redux to React components?
questions.answer: Use react-redux hooks: useSelector to select state slices; connect() with mapStateToProps is alternative. Ensure selectors are memoized for perf.

questions.title: Where to keep API integration logic in Redux architecture?
questions.answer: Keep API logic in thunks/async actions, RTK Query endpoints, or separate services. Avoid placing heavy logic in reducers; use middleware for side-effects.

questions.title: Where to keep Thunks or Sagas in Redux folder structure?
questions.answer: Place thunks/sagas under state feature folders, e.g., features/products/thunks.js or features/products/sagas.js, and import them into store configuration.

questions.title: What is Middleware in Redux?
questions.answer: Middleware is a way to extend Redux with custom behavior between dispatch and reducer: ({getState, dispatch}) => next => action.

questions.title: Why to use Middleware in Redux?
questions.answer: Middleware handles side-effects (async), logging, routing, analytics, and action transformations without polluting reducers.

questions.title: When to use Middleware in Redux?
questions.answer: Use middleware when dealing with async calls, logging, conditional dispatch, or cross-cutting concerns like retries or caching.

questions.title: In which scenarios Middlewares are required in Redux?
questions.answer: Scenarios: async API calls, optimistic updates, logging, crash reporting, authentication token refresh, complex side-effect orchestration.

questions.title: What are the types of Middlewares in Redux?
questions.answer: Common types: logging, async (thunk), saga, observable, promise middleware, serializability checks, custom analytics middleware.

questions.title: What is Redux Logger Middleware?
questions.answer: Redux Logger logs actions and state before/after each dispatch, helping debug state transitions in development.

questions.title: What is Redux Thunk Middleware?
questions.answer: Redux Thunk allows action creators to return functions (thunks) that receive dispatch/getState for async logic and conditional dispatching.

questions.title: What is Redux Saga Middleware?
questions.answer: Redux Saga middleware runs generator-based sagas to handle complex async flows using yield effects for clearer control flow and testability.

questions.title: What is Redux Observable Middleware?
questions.answer: Redux Observable integrates RxJS with Redux to express async flows as observable streams and operators, great for complex event handling.

questions.title: What is Redux Promise Middleware?
questions.answer: Promise middleware handles actions that carry promises by dispatching pending/fulfilled/rejected actions automatically.

questions.title: What is Redux Thunk?
questions.answer: Redux Thunk is a simple middleware enabling async logic in action creators by returning functions instead of plain actions.

questions.title: Why to use Redux Thunk?
questions.answer: Use Thunk for straightforward async tasks like fetching data, simple control flow, and easy migration from synchronous action creators.

questions.title: How Redux Thunk works internally?
questions.answer: Thunk checks if dispatched item is function: if so, calls it with dispatch and getState; otherwise passes action to next middleware/reducer.

questions.title: What is the syntax of Redux Thunk?
questions.answer: Basic thunk: const fetchData = () => async (dispatch, getState) => { dispatch(start()); const data = await api(); dispatch(success(data)); }

questions.title: When to use Redux Thunk?
questions.answer: Use Redux when app state is shared by many components, when state changes are complex, or when you need predictable state transitions and tooling like DevTools.

questions.title: What are the use cases of Redux Thunk?
questions.answer: Use cases: fetching resources, conditional dispatching, simple retries, optimistic updates orchestrated in action creators.

questions.title: In which scenarios did you use Redux Thunk in your eCommerce project?
questions.answer: Example: used Thunk to fetch product lists, cart operations, and handle auth flows where simple sequential async logic sufficed.

questions.title: What are the advantages of Redux Thunk?
questions.answer: Advantages: simple API, minimal boilerplate, easy to learn, compatible with existing action creators.

questions.title: What are the limitations of Redux Thunk?
questions.answer: Limitations: can lead to scattered async logic, harder to test complex flows, and becomes unwieldy for complex orchestrations.

questions.title: What is the main difference between Redux Thunk and Redux Saga?
questions.answer: Thunk uses functions for simple async; Saga uses generator functions for declarative side-effect management and powerful control flows (cancellation, concurrency).

questions.title: If Redux Thunk exists, why do we need Redux Saga?
questions.answer: Short answer: If Redux Thunk exists, why do we need Redux Saga?

questions.title: What is Redux Saga?
questions.answer: Redux Saga is middleware using ES6 generators to manage complex async flows as sagas with declarative effects.

questions.title: Why to use Redux Saga?
questions.answer: Use Saga for advanced side-effect handling, long-running processes, orchestrating multiple async tasks, and cancellation support.

questions.title: When to use Redux Saga?
questions.answer: Use Redux when app state is shared by many components, when state changes are complex, or when you need predictable state transitions and tooling like DevTools.

questions.title: What are the topics/concepts in Redux Saga?
questions.answer: Key concepts: sagas (watchers/workers), effects (call, put, take, fork, cancel), takeEvery/takeLatest, channels, and testing sagas.

questions.title: What are the advantages of Redux Saga over Redux Thunk?
questions.answer: Saga advantages: declarative effects, better control over concurrency, cancellation, easier to test complex flows, improved composition.

questions.title: What are the use cases of Redux Saga?
questions.answer: Use cases: payment flows, background sync, complex retries/backoff, websockets management, orchestrating multiple API calls.

questions.title: Where did you use Redux Saga in your eCommerce project?
questions.answer: Example: used Saga for checkout flow orchestration, payment retries, and websocket order updates where complex orchestration was needed.

questions.title: What is the syntax of Redux Saga?
questions.answer: Saga example: function* worker(action){ try{ const res = yield call(api, action.payload); yield put({type: "SUCCESS", payload: res}); } catch(e){ yield put({type:"FAIL", error: e}); } } function* watcher(){ yield takeEvery("REQUEST", worker); }

questions.title: How Redux Saga works internally?
questions.answer: Sagas yield effect objects to the middleware which interprets them (call, put, take) and runs corresponding async operations, enabling the generator to pause/resume.

questions.title: What is a Saga Watcher?
questions.answer: Watcher listens for dispatched actions (e.g., takeEvery/takeLatest) and spawns worker sagas to handle those actions.

questions.title: What is a Saga Worker?
questions.answer: Worker is the saga that performs the actual side-effect (API call, dispatch actions) often invoked by a watcher.

questions.title: What are Effects in Redux Saga?
questions.answer: Effects are plain objects representing instructions (call, put, take, fork, cancel) that saga middleware interprets and executes.

questions.title: What is call(), put(), takeEvery(), takeLatest(), delay(), fork(), cancel()?
questions.answer: call(fn,args): invoke function; put(action): dispatch action; takeEvery(pattern,worker): spawn worker for each action; takeLatest: cancel previous and keep latest; delay(ms): wait; fork: non-blocking task spawn; cancel: cancel forked task.

questions.title: What is the flow of implementing Redux Saga?
questions.answer: Flow: write worker sagas, write watcher sagas, combine sagas in rootSaga, run saga middleware via sagaMiddleware.run(rootSaga) in store configuration.

questions.title: How to combine Redux Thunk and Redux Saga in the same app?
questions.answer: You can apply both middleware when creating store: applyMiddleware(thunk, sagaMiddleware). Use one for specific features; avoid conflicting responsibilities.

questions.title: What is Redux Toolkit (RTK)?
questions.answer: Redux Toolkit (RTK) is the official, opinionated Redux toolset that simplifies store setup, reducers, and common patterns with createSlice, configureStore, and createAsyncThunk.

questions.title: Why to use Redux Toolkit?
questions.answer: Use RTK to reduce boilerplate, prevent common mistakes, include good defaults (Immer, DevTools), and speed up development.

questions.title: When to use Redux Toolkit?
questions.answer: Use Redux when app state is shared by many components, when state changes are complex, or when you need predictable state transitions and tooling like DevTools.

questions.title: What problems does Redux Toolkit solve?
questions.answer: RTK solves boilerplate, encourages immutable updates via Immer, provides standardized patterns (slices, thunks), and integrates DevTools and middleware.

questions.title: What are the benefits of Redux Toolkit over normal Redux?
questions.answer: Benefits: less boilerplate, built-in best practices, standardized APIs (createSlice, configureStore), built-in immutability via Immer, and RTK Query for data fetching.

questions.title: What is createSlice() in Redux Toolkit?
questions.answer: createSlice simplifies reducer creation by defining initial state, reducers, and auto-generating action creators and types.

questions.title: What is configureStore() in Redux Toolkit?
questions.answer: configureStore wraps createStore with good defaults: sets up thunk, immutable/serializable middleware, DevTools, and accepts reducers and enhancers.

questions.title: What is createAsyncThunk() in Redux Toolkit?
questions.answer: createAsyncThunk simplifies async logic by auto-generating pending/fulfilled/rejected action types and handling dispatch lifecycle for async calls.

questions.title: What is RTK Query in Redux Toolkit?
questions.answer: RTK Query is a data fetching and caching solution built into RTK that simplifies fetching, caching, invalidation, and auto-generated hooks.

questions.title: What is the flow of implementing Redux Toolkit?
questions.answer: Flow: define slices with createSlice, combine slices in configureStore, use createAsyncThunk for async operations or RTK Query, then use useSelector/useDispatch in components.

questions.title: What are real-time use cases of Redux Toolkit?
questions.answer: Use RTK for CRUD apps, forms, caching API responses, optimistic updates, and replacing verbose reducer/action boilerplate.

questions.title: Where did you use Redux Toolkit in your eCommerce project?
questions.answer: Example: used RTK to manage product slices, cart logic, and RTK Query for product list caching and auto refetch on focus.

questions.title: What is the difference between Reducer and Slice in RTK?
questions.answer: A slice bundles reducer logic + actions for a feature; reducer is the function alone. createSlice creates reducer plus action creators/types automatically.

questions.title: How does createSlice reduce boilerplate code?
questions.answer: createSlice auto-generates action types and creators and lets you write mutable-looking code using Immer while producing immutable updates.

questions.title: How Redux Toolkit handles immutability using Immer?
questions.answer: Short answer: How Redux Toolkit handles immutability using Immer?

questions.title: How to structure Redux Toolkit folder architecture in real projects?
questions.answer: Short answer: How to structure Redux Toolkit folder architecture in real projects?

questions.title: How to integrate API calls in Redux Toolkit?
questions.answer: Use createAsyncThunk for ad-hoc async flows or RTK Query for standardized, cache-first data fetching with auto-generated hooks and cache invalidation.

questions.title: What is the difference between Thunk and createAsyncThunk?
questions.answer: createAsyncThunk standardizes async lifecycle and generates action types for pending/fulfilled/rejected; thunk is a general function pattern with more manual wiring.

questions.title: What are the benefits of createAsyncThunk?
questions.answer: Benefits: less boilerplate, consistent action types, auto dispatch of lifecycle actions, built-in error serialization support and integration with RTK.

questions.title: How to write reducers for async lifecycle: pending, fulfilled, rejected?
questions.answer: Handle createAsyncThunk lifecycle in extraReducers: builder.addCase(thunk.pending), .addCase(thunk.fulfilled), .addCase(thunk.rejected) to update state accordingly.

questions.title: Where to keep Thunks/Sagas in Redux Toolkit?
questions.answer: Short answer: Where to keep Thunks/Sagas in Redux Toolkit?

questions.title: How to connect Redux Toolkit store to React components?
questions.answer: Wrap app in <Provider store={store}> created with configureStore. Use useSelector/useDispatch or RTK Query generated hooks to access/modify state.

questions.title: How to fetch state using useSelector with RTK?
questions.answer: useSelector(state => state.featureName.someValue) selects state slices; use memoized selectors (reselect) for performance.

questions.title: How to dispatch actions using useDispatch with RTK?
questions.answer: const dispatch = useDispatch(); dispatch(slice.actions.someAction(payload)) or dispatch(createAsyncThunkAction()).

questions.title: How to optimize state updates in Redux Toolkit?
questions.answer: Short answer: How to optimize state updates in Redux Toolkit?

questions.title: What is the difference between RTK Query and Thunk?
questions.answer: RTK Query is a specialized data-fetching/cache layer with auto-hooks and caching; thunks are general-purpose async functions you write manually.

questions.title: What is the difference between RTK Query and Axios?
questions.answer: Axios is an HTTP client; RTK Query builds on fetch/axios to add caching, invalidation, and auto-generated hooksâ€”it is higher-level than raw HTTP clients.

questions.title: What is Serializability Middleware in RTK?
questions.answer: Serializability middleware checks actions/state for non-serializable values to ensure actions/state can be persisted and DevTools work reliably.

questions.title: What is Immutable Check Middleware?
questions.answer: Immutable check middleware warns when state is mutated between dispatches, helping catch accidental mutations during development.

questions.title: What is DevTools Enhancer built into RTK?
questions.answer: RTK configures Redux DevTools enhancer by default for development to enable time-travel debugging and action/state inspection.

questions.title: How Redux Toolkit improves performance?
questions.answer: RTK improves DX and reduces bugs; performance improvements come from recommended patterns, Immer optimizations, RTK Query caching, and encouraging normalized state.

questions.title: What is the recommended Redux architecture by the Redux Team?
questions.answer: Redux team recommends feature-folder structure (ducks pattern / features), use of RTK createSlice/configureStore, keeping async logic in thunks/RTK Query, and keeping UI state local.

questions.title: What is Node.js?
questions.answer: Node.js is a JavaScript runtime built on Chrome's V8 engine that allows executing JavaScript on the server. It provides an event-driven, non-blocking I/O model that makes it lightweight and efficient for building scalable network applications and APIs.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Server-side JavaScript
â€¢ APIs
â€¢ Real-time apps
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ REST APIs
â€¢ WebSocket servers
â€¢ CLI tools

questions.title: Why use Node.js?
questions.answer: Use Node.js when you need high concurrency, low-latency I/O, and a single-language stack across client and server. Its non-blocking model and rich npm ecosystem speed up development for real-time applications, microservices, and streaming workloads.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Real-time services
â€¢ Microservices
â€¢ Lightweight APIs
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Chat apps
â€¢ Realtime dashboards
â€¢ Streaming servers

questions.title: What are the features of Node.js?
questions.answer: Key features include the V8 engine for fast JS execution, an event-driven, non-blocking I/O model, a single-threaded event loop for concurrency, a built-in package manager (npm), and a rich standard library for network and filesystem operations.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ High-concurrency servers
â€¢ Streaming
â€¢ Tooling
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ File streaming
â€¢ Proxy servers
â€¢ API gateways

questions.title: What is the V8 engine in Node.js?
questions.answer: V8 is Google's open-source JavaScript engine that compiles JS to native machine code. Node embeds V8 to execute JavaScript at high speed; V8 also provides optimizations like inline caching and JIT compilation.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Fast JS execution
â€¢ JIT optimizations
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Performance-critical code
â€¢ CPU-bound tasks with native addons

questions.title: What is the Event Loop in Node.js?
questions.answer: The event loop is the core mechanism that handles asynchronous callbacks and I/O in Node. It repeatedly checks queues of pending tasks (timers, I/O callbacks, microtasks) and dispatches them, giving the appearance of concurrency on a single thread.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Managing async work
â€¢ Coordinating callbacks/promises
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Handling thousands of concurrent connections
â€¢ Non-blocking I/O

questions.title: Explain Event-Driven Architecture in Node.js.
questions.answer: Event-driven architecture centers on emitting and reacting to events. In Node, modules (like EventEmitter) emit events when something happens, and listeners handle them; this decouples producers from consumers and fits well with I/O-driven server workflows.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Decoupled services
â€¢ Reactive designs
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ WebSocket event handling
â€¢ Background job notifications

questions.title: What is Non-Blocking I/O in Node.js?
questions.answer: Non-blocking I/O means I/O operations are initiated and callbacks are used when they complete, so the main thread isn't blocked waiting for results. This allows Node to handle many simultaneous operations efficiently.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ High throughput servers
â€¢ I/O-heavy tasks
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ File uploads
â€¢ Proxying requests

questions.title: What are Callbacks in Node.js?
questions.answer: Callbacks are functions passed as arguments and invoked when async operations finish. They were the primary async pattern in Node, but can lead to nested code (callback hell) and are often replaced by promises/async-await for clearer flow control.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Handling async results
â€¢ Legacy APIs
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ fs.readFile callbacks
â€¢ network request callbacks

questions.title: What are Promises in Node.js?
questions.answer: Promises represent the eventual completion or failure of an async operation, providing .then/.catch chains for handling results and errors. They improve readability over callbacks and can be combined with Promise.all, race, and other helpers.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Async control flow
â€¢ Composing parallel tasks
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Multiple API calls aggregation
â€¢ Retry logic

questions.title: What is async/await in Node.js?
questions.answer: async/await builds on promises to express asynchronous code in a synchronous-like style. An async function returns a promise; await pauses execution until the promise resolves, making code easier to read and reason about.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Cleaner async code
â€¢ Sequential async flows
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Database access sequences
â€¢ Readable API handlers

questions.title: Explain Microtask Queue vs Macrotask Queue.
questions.answer: Microtasks (promise callbacks, process.nextTick) run at the end of the current task before the event loop proceeds. Macrotasks (timers, I/O callbacks, setImmediate) are scheduled for later phases. Microtasks have higher priority, so they can starve macrotasks if abused.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Promise scheduling
â€¢ Task prioritization
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Ensuring immediate promise resolution before I/O callbacks

questions.title: What is Synchronous vs Asynchronous communication?
questions.answer: Synchronous communication blocks until a response arrives (calling thread waits). Asynchronous communication initiates work and continues; results are delivered via callbacks/promises/events. Asynchronous approaches improve throughput and responsiveness in I/O-bound systems.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ API design
â€¢ Microservices communication
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Blocking DB calls vs async queries
â€¢ Event-driven messaging

questions.title: What is the difference between process.nextTick() and setImmediate()?
questions.answer: process.nextTick queues a callback to run immediately after the current operation completes (before I/O), while setImmediate schedules a callback to run on the next iteration of the event loop (after I/O callbacks). Use nextTick for truly immediate microtasks and setImmediate for deferring to the next loop turn.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Microtask scheduling
â€¢ Avoiding recursion
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Deferring heavy work
â€¢ Breaking up long synchronous loops

questions.title: What is the difference between setTimeout(), setInterval(), and setImmediate()?
questions.answer: setTimeout schedules a callback after a minimum delay; setInterval repeats a callback at intervals; setImmediate executes a callback on the next event loop iteration. For repeated work, prefer setInterval or self-scheduling setTimeout; setImmediate is useful for deferring to the next cycle without a time delay.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Timed operations
â€¢ Deferring tasks
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Polling
â€¢ Debounced retries

questions.title: What is the difference between CommonJS and ES Modules?
questions.answer: CommonJS (require/module.exports) is Node's original module system with synchronous loading. ES Modules (import/export) is the standardized module system with static analysis and support for import/export syntax; ESM supports asynchronous loading and tree-shaking. Node supports both with different interop rules.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Module design
â€¢ Tooling compatibility
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Authoring libraries
â€¢ Using modern build tools

questions.title: What is the require() function and how it works?
questions.answer: require() loads modules using a path or package name, resolves module IDs, loads and executes the module code, and returns module.exports. Node caches loaded modules to avoid re-execution on subsequent requires.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Loading local modules
â€¢ Using npm packages
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ App composition
â€¢ Plugin systems

questions.title: What is Module Caching in Node.js?
questions.answer: Node caches modules after first load in require.cache; subsequent require calls return the cached exports. This improves performance and preserves singleton behavior but requires care when you need fresh state (clear cache or use dynamic import).
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Database connection singletons
â€¢ Configuration modules

questions.title: What is NPM?
questions.answer: npm is the default package manager for Node.js, providing a registry of packages, dependency resolution, and scripts defined in package.json. It simplifies package installation, versioning, and publishing.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Dependency management
â€¢ Scripts automation
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Installing libraries
â€¢ Running build/test scripts

questions.title: What is package.json?
questions.answer: package.json is a manifest describing a Node project: metadata, dependencies, scripts, and configuration. It defines how to install, run, and publish the package.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Project metadata
â€¢ Dependency list
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ npm install
â€¢ npm run scripts

questions.title: What is package-lock.json?
questions.answer: package-lock.json records exact versions of installed dependencies and their dependency tree, ensuring deterministic installs across environments. It's generated automatically and should be committed for reproducible builds.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Reproducible installs
â€¢ CI consistency
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Locking dependency tree in production

questions.title: What are Node.js Streams?
questions.answer: Streams are abstractions for working with streaming data, allowing processing of data piece-by-piece rather than in a single buffer. They reduce memory usage and allow piping between sources and destinations (e.g., file read stream -> gzip -> HTTP response).
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Processing large data
â€¢ Piping transforms
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ File uploads/downloads
â€¢ Streaming video/audio

questions.title: Types of Streams in Node.js.
questions.answer: Four main types: Readable (read data), Writable (write data), Duplex (read and write), and Transform (a Duplex that modifies data). Each has an object-mode option and implements backpressure to avoid overwhelming consumers.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Stream composition
â€¢ Transform pipelines
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Compression pipelines
â€¢ ETL processes

questions.title: What are Buffers in Node.js?
questions.answer: Buffers are raw binary data containers used to handle streams and binary protocols. They provide methods to read/write integers, strings with encodings, and slice without copying, which is useful for network and file I/O.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Binary protocols
â€¢ Data parsing
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ TCP protocol handling
â€¢ Image processing

questions.title: What is the File System (fs) module?
questions.answer: The fs module provides APIs to interact with the file system: reading/writing files, watching changes, streaming file contents, and more. It offers both synchronous and asynchronous variants; prefer async to avoid blocking the event loop.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ File I/O
â€¢ Config management
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Serving static files
â€¢ Log rotation

questions.title: What is the Crypto module?
questions.answer: Crypto provides cryptographic primitives: hashing, HMAC, cipher algorithms, key pair generation, and signing. Use it for secure operations like password hashing, data integrity verification, and TLS-related tasks.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Signing tokens
â€¢ Secure storage

questions.title: What is JWT and how it works in Node.js?
questions.answer: JWT (JSON Web Token) is a compact token format containing claims, signed (and optionally encrypted). In Node, servers create a JWT signed with a secret/private key and return it to clients; clients present it for authenticated requests and the server verifies signature and claims.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Access tokens
â€¢ Single-page app auth

questions.title: What is Middleware in Node.js?
questions.answer: Middleware is reusable code that sits between request and response (commonly in Express). It can modify requests/responses, handle authentication, logging, or perform validation, and is composed in a pipeline to build request-handling logic.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Auth
â€¢ Logging
â€¢ Validation
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ JWT verification
â€¢ Request body parsing

questions.title: What is Express.js?
questions.answer: Express is a minimal, flexible web framework for Node providing routing, middleware support, and utilities to build APIs and server-side apps quickly. It's widely used for REST APIs and microservices.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ REST services
â€¢ Static servers

questions.title: What are Express routers?
questions.answer: Express Routers are modular route handlers that group related routes and middleware. They help organize application structure by mounting routers on path prefixes and isolating route logic.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Modular routes
â€¢ Versioned APIs
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ User routes
â€¢ Admin routes

questions.title: What is CORS?
questions.answer: CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing) is a browser security mechanism controlling cross-origin requests. Servers return CORS headers to indicate allowed origins, methods, and headers. Proper CORS config enables APIs to be safely accessed from web apps on different domains.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ API security
â€¢ Cross-origin requests
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Public APIs
â€¢ Microfrontends

questions.title: What is Helmet?
questions.answer: Helmet is Express middleware that sets various HTTP headers to improve security (e.g., Content-Security-Policy, X-Frame-Options). It reduces common web vulnerabilities by providing sensible defaults and configuration options.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Hardening HTTP headers
â€¢ Security defaults
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Protecting against clickjacking
â€¢ Content security policies

questions.title: What is Rate Limiting in Node.js?
questions.answer: Rate limiting restricts the number of requests a client can make in a time window to prevent abuse and DoS. Implementations use in-memory stores, Redis, or external API gateways to track and enforce limits.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ API protection
â€¢ Abuse prevention
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Login throttling
â€¢ Public API quotas

questions.title: What is Throttling in Node.js?
questions.answer: Throttling limits how often a function or endpoint executes over time to smooth load and avoid spikes. It's commonly applied to expensive operations or user actions to keep resource usage predictable.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Rate control
â€¢ Smoothing spikes
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Search queries
â€¢ Autosave operations

questions.title: What is clustering in Node.js?
questions.answer: Clustering runs multiple Node worker processes (usually one per CPU) sharing server ports to utilize multi-core CPUs. The cluster or worker_threads modules help scale CPU-bound workloads and improve availability.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ High-traffic servers
â€¢ Parallel batch jobs

questions.title: What is Load Balancing?
questions.answer: Load balancing distributes incoming traffic across multiple instances to improve availability and throughput. It can be done by reverse proxies (NGINX), cloud load balancers, or API gateways with health checks and session strategies.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Horizontal scaling behind NGINX
â€¢ Blue/green deployments

questions.title: What is PM2 and why use it?
questions.answer: PM2 is a process manager for Node.js that handles process monitoring, clustering, log management, and graceful restarts. It simplifies deployment and ensures apps stay running in production.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Process management
â€¢ Zero-downtime restarts
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Managing multiple services
â€¢ Auto-restarts on crash

questions.title: What are environment variables?
questions.answer: Environment variables are key/value pairs provided to processes by the OS to configure behavior (e.g., PORT, NODE_ENV). They enable separating configuration from code and are commonly used for secrets, endpoints, and flags.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Config management
â€¢ Secrets handling
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Setting DB URLs
â€¢ Feature flags

questions.title: What is dotenv and why use it?
questions.answer: dotenv is a utility that loads environment variables from a .env file into process.env during development. It simplifies local config while keeping secrets out of source code, but .env should not be committed to source control for sensitive values.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Local configuration
â€¢ Developer convenience
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Local DB credentials
â€¢ Dev feature toggles

questions.title: What is REST API?
questions.answer: REST (Representational State Transfer) is an architectural style for designing networked applications using stateless HTTP endpoints, resource-based URIs, and standard methods (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE). REST APIs are simple to implement and widely used for web services.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Web services
â€¢ CRUD APIs
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ User management APIs
â€¢ Public service endpoints

questions.title: What is gRPC?
questions.answer: gRPC is a high-performance RPC framework using HTTP/2 and Protocol Buffers for schema-defined contracts. It supports streaming, bi-directional communication, and strong typing, making it suitable for microservices and low-latency services.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Microservices communication
â€¢ Streaming RPC
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Inter-service RPC
â€¢ Low-latency APIs

questions.title: What are Microservices?
questions.answer: Microservices are an architectural style where an application is composed of small, independently deployable services that communicate over lightweight protocols. They improve modularity and scalability but add complexity in deployment, observability, and data consistency.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Domain-driven design
â€¢ Independent scaling
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Payment service
â€¢ User service

questions.title: What is API Gateway?
questions.answer: An API Gateway is a faÃ§ade that routes, secures, and aggregates calls to backend services. It can provide authentication, rate limiting, caching, and protocol translation, centralizing cross-cutting concerns for microservices.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Auth enforcement
â€¢ Request routing

questions.title: What is Redis?
questions.answer: Redis is an in-memory key-value store used for caching, ephemeral storage, pub/sub, and simple data structures. It's extremely fast and useful for reducing DB load and sharing state among services.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Caching
â€¢ Session store
â€¢ Pub/Sub
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Token cache
â€¢ Leader election

questions.title: What is Redis Caching?
questions.answer: Redis caching stores frequently accessed data in memory to reduce latency and decrease backend load. Common patterns include read-through, write-through, and cache-aside, with eviction policies like LRU and TTL.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Page caching
â€¢ Query result caching

questions.title: What is Redis Pub/Sub?
questions.answer: Redis Pub/Sub is a lightweight messaging mechanism where publishers send messages to channels and subscribers receive them in real-time. It's useful for simple notifications but lacks persistence and advanced messaging guarantees.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Realtime notifications
â€¢ Event broadcast
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Chat messages
â€¢ Cache invalidation

questions.title: What is Message Queue (RabbitMQ/Kafka)?
questions.answer: Message queues decouple producers from consumers by buffering messages. RabbitMQ is a broker supporting complex routing and acknowledgments; Kafka is a distributed log optimized for high-throughput streaming and replayability. They enable resilient, asynchronous architectures.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Order processing
â€¢ Event streaming

questions.title: What is Bull Queue in Node.js?
questions.answer: Bull is a Redis-backed queue library for Node that supports job retries, scheduling, concurrency control, and rate limiting. It's commonly used for background jobs like sending emails, generating reports, or processing uploads.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Background jobs
â€¢ Retryable tasks
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Email sending
â€¢ Video transcoding

questions.title: What is WebSocket?
questions.answer: WebSocket is a protocol providing full-duplex communication channels over a single TCP connection, enabling low-latency, bidirectional data exchange between client and server.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Realtime apps
â€¢ Push updates
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Chat apps
â€¢ Realtime dashboards

questions.title: What is Socket.IO?
questions.answer: Socket.IO is a library that provides real-time, bidirectional communication with fallback transports and additional features like rooms and reconnection handling. It builds on WebSocket where available and provides a higher-level API.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Realtime collaboration
â€¢ Transport fallback
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Live chat
â€¢ Collaborative editing

questions.title: What is SSE (Server-Sent Events)?
questions.answer: SSE is a unidirectional streaming protocol where the server pushes text/event-stream data to the client over an HTTP connection. It's simpler than WebSocket for server-to-client updates and works well for streaming notifications.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Server push
â€¢ Live updates
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Stock tickers
â€¢ Live news feeds

questions.title: Explain real-time communication in Node.js.
questions.answer: Real-time communication in Node uses WebSocket, Socket.IO, or SSE to deliver low-latency messages. Node's event-driven model fits real-time workloads; proper scaling requires sticky sessions, shared pub/sub (e.g., Redis), or message brokers to distribute events across instances.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Low-latency apps
â€¢ Collaborative tools
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Chat
â€¢ Live collaboration

questions.title: What is Horizontal Scaling?
questions.answer: Horizontal scaling adds more instances to handle increased load (scale out). It improves throughput and availability and is typically achieved with load balancers and stateless services.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Autoscaling clusters
â€¢ Service farms

questions.title: What is Vertical Scaling?
questions.answer: Vertical scaling increases resources (CPU, RAM) of a single machine (scale up). It can be simpler but has limits and can be a single point of failure.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Short-term scaling
â€¢ Resource heavy tasks
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Upgrading DB server
â€¢ Memory-heavy processes

questions.title: What is Horizontal Pod Autoscaling (Kubernetes)?
questions.answer: HPA automatically scales the number of pod replicas based on CPU/memory or custom metrics, enabling applications to adapt to changing load within Kubernetes clusters.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ K8s autoscaling
â€¢ Resource optimization
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Scaling API pods
â€¢ Handling traffic spikes

questions.title: What is Docker?
questions.answer: Docker is a containerization platform that packages applications and dependencies into lightweight, portable containers, ensuring consistent behavior across environments.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Microservices
â€¢ CI builds

questions.title: What is Dockerfile?
questions.answer: A Dockerfile is a text file with instructions to build a Docker image, specifying base image, files to copy, environment variables, and commands to run during image creation.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Image creation
â€¢ Repeatable builds
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Containerizing apps
â€¢ Reproducible dev environments

questions.title: What is docker-compose?
questions.answer: docker-compose is a tool to define and run multi-container Docker applications using a YAML file, orchestrating how services, networks, and volumes interact locally.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Local orchestration
â€¢ Multi-service dev stacks
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Local microservices
â€¢ DB + API stacks

questions.title: What is Kubernetes?
questions.answer: Kubernetes is a container orchestration system for automating deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications across clusters.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Running microservices in production
â€¢ Service discovery

questions.title: What is a Pod, Deployment, and Service in K8s?
questions.answer: A Pod is the smallest deployable unit (one or more containers); a Deployment manages desired state and rolling updates; a Service exposes pods via stable endpoints and load-balances traffic.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Container lifecycle
â€¢ Service exposure
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Stateless app deployments
â€¢ Blue/green updates

questions.title: What is CI/CD?
questions.answer: CI/CD is a set of practices (Continuous Integration/Continuous Delivery) that automate building, testing, and deploying code changes to improve release velocity and reliability.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Pipeline automation
â€¢ Quality gates
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Automated testing
â€¢ Production deployments

questions.title: What is GitHub Actions/Jenkins in CI/CD?
questions.answer: GitHub Actions and Jenkins are CI/CD tools: GitHub Actions provides integrated pipelines in GitHub; Jenkins is a highly extensible automation server. Both run build/test/deploy pipelines and integrate with external services.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Automated builds
â€¢ Testing pipelines
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Run tests on PRs
â€¢ Deploy on merge

questions.title: What is Unit Testing in Node.js?
questions.answer: Unit testing verifies individual units (functions/modules) in isolation using assertions and mocks. It ensures code correctness and enables safe refactoring.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Regression prevention
â€¢ Design feedback
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Testing utility functions
â€¢ Testing services

questions.title: What is Integration Testing in Node.js?
questions.answer: Integration testing checks interactions between components (e.g., API + DB) to validate end-to-end behavior for specific workflows.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Data layer testing
â€¢ API-contracts
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Testing endpoints with test DB
â€¢ Third-party integrations

questions.title: What is E2E Testing in Node.js?
questions.answer: End-to-end testing validates entire user flows through the system from UI to backend, often using tools like Playwright or Selenium to simulate real user interactions.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ User flow validation
â€¢ Regression checks
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Checkout flow tests
â€¢ Multi-step forms

questions.title: What is Mocha, Jest, Chai, Supertest?
questions.answer: Mocha and Jest are test runners; Jest includes assertion library and mocking utilities. Chai is an assertion library often used with Mocha. Supertest helps test HTTP endpoints. Together they provide a testing stack for Node apps.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Unit & integration testing
â€¢ HTTP assertions
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ API tests
â€¢ Snapshot testing

questions.title: What is Logging in Node.js?
questions.answer: Logging records application behavior and errors. Structured logs with timestamps, levels, and request context are critical for debugging and observability.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Error tracking
â€¢ Request logs

questions.title: What is Winston Logger?
questions.answer: Winston is a flexible logging library supporting multiple transports, log levels, and formats. It's commonly used for production logging to files, consoles, and external systems.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Production logging
â€¢ Multiple transports
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Log files
â€¢ Remote log aggregation

questions.title: What is Morgan Logger?
questions.answer: Morgan is an HTTP request logger middleware for Express that logs request/response metadata for development and basic production needs.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Access logs
â€¢ Development diagnostics

questions.title: What is Monitoring in Node.js?
questions.answer: Monitoring collects metrics, logs, and traces to observe application health. It includes uptime checks, performance metrics, and alerting to detect and react to issues.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Health checks
â€¢ Performance tracking
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ CPU/memory alerts
â€¢ Error rate monitoring

questions.title: What is Prometheus?
questions.answer: Prometheus is an open-source monitoring system that scrapes metrics exposed over HTTP and stores time-series data; it's commonly used with Grafana for visualization.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Service metrics
â€¢ SLO monitoring

questions.title: What is Grafana?
questions.answer: Grafana is a dashboarding and visualization tool used to graph metrics and build operational dashboards from Prometheus and other data sources.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Performance dashboards
â€¢ SLA reporting

questions.title: What is OpenTelemetry?
questions.answer: OpenTelemetry is a vendor-neutral observability framework for instrumenting code to produce traces, metrics, and logs; it standardizes telemetry collection and export.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Tracing microservices
â€¢ Unified telemetry

questions.title: What is Distributed Tracing?
questions.answer: Distributed tracing tracks a request across service boundaries by propagating trace context and recording spans, enabling root-cause analysis and latency breakdowns across microservices.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Performance debugging
â€¢ Latency analysis
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Tracing slow requests
â€¢ Span correlations

questions.title: What is NGINX reverse proxy?
questions.answer: NGINX can act as a reverse proxy that routes requests to backend servers, performs TLS termination, caching, and load balancing, improving security and performance.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ TLS offloading
â€¢ Load balancing
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Serving static assets
â€¢ API gateway proxying

questions.title: What is HTTPS and TLS in Node.js?
questions.answer: HTTPS secures HTTP with TLS encryption; Node supports HTTPS via the https module, requiring certificates and keys. TLS ensures confidentiality, integrity, and authentication for web traffic.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Secure traffic
â€¢ Data privacy
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Secure APIs
â€¢ Payment processing

questions.title: What is CSRF?
questions.answer: CSRF (Cross-Site Request Forgery) is an attack where a user's browser is tricked into submitting unintended requests. Mitigations include CSRF tokens, SameSite cookies, and checking Origin/Referer headers.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Web security
â€¢ Form protection
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Protecting state-changing endpoints
â€¢ Form submissions

questions.title: What is XSS?
questions.answer: XSS (Cross-Site Scripting) allows attackers to inject client-side scripts into pages viewed by others. Prevent by escaping/untrusted content, using Content Security Policy, and sanitizing inputs.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Frontend security
â€¢ Input validation
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Sanitizing user comments
â€¢ CSP enforcement

questions.title: What is SQL Injection?
questions.answer: SQL injection occurs when untrusted input alters SQL queries; prevent it using parameterized queries/ORMs, input validation, and least privilege DB users.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ DB security
â€¢ Query safety
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Prepared statements
â€¢ ORM parameter binding

questions.title: What is Input Validation?
questions.answer: Input validation ensures incoming data meets expected formats and constraints. It prevents injection attacks, runtime errors, and data corruption by using schemas and validation libraries.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Validating API payloads
â€¢ Form validation

questions.title: What is Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)?
questions.answer: RBAC assigns permissions to roles which are then granted to users, simplifying permission management and enforcing least privilege across the system.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Access management
â€¢ Permission modeling
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Admin vs user roles
â€¢ Feature toggles

questions.title: What are Access Tokens and Refresh Tokens?
questions.answer: Access tokens grant clients access to resources for a short period; refresh tokens are long-lived and used to obtain new access tokens without reauthenticating. This pattern balances security and usability.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Token-based auth
â€¢ Session management
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ JWT access/refresh flows
â€¢ OAuth2 implementations

questions.title: What is session-based authentication vs token-based authentication?
questions.answer: Session-based auth stores session state on server (session id cookie), while token-based (e.g., JWT) stores auth claims on client; sessions simplify revocation, tokens enable stateless scaling and cross-domain usage.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Auth strategies
â€¢ Scalability considerations
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Web apps with server sessions
â€¢ SPAs using JWT

questions.title: What is the difference between Express.js and NestJS?
questions.answer: Express is minimal and unopinionated; NestJS is a framework built on top of Express (or Fastify) that uses TypeScript, dependency injection, and modular architecture for enterprise-grade apps.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Lightweight apps
â€¢ Structured enterprise apps
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Small APIs with Express
â€¢ Large apps with NestJS

questions.title: What is Koa.js?
questions.answer: Koa is a lightweight, modern web framework from the Express team that uses async functions and a middleware stack to create smaller, more expressive servers.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Minimal middleware
â€¢ Modern patterns
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Microservices
â€¢ Custom middleware stacks

questions.title: What is Hapi.js?
questions.answer: Hapi is a rich framework focused on configuration and extensibility, offering plugins, validation, and built-in patterns for building robust APIs.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Enterprise APIs
â€¢ Plugin ecosystems
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Policy-driven APIs
â€¢ Secure services

questions.title: What is EventEmitter in Node.js?
questions.answer: EventEmitter is the core pub/sub utility in Node that allows objects to emit events and register listeners. It's widely used in core modules and userland code for building evented APIs.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Event pub/sub
â€¢ Custom event APIs
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Stream events
â€¢ Custom hooks

questions.title: What is process object in Node.js?
questions.answer: process is a global object that provides info and control over the Node process (argv, env, exit, stdout/stderr), enabling interaction with the runtime environment.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Process control
â€¢ Accessing env vars
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Graceful shutdown
â€¢ Reading CLI args

questions.title: What are child processes?
questions.answer: Child processes allow Node to spawn external processes (spawn, exec, fork) to run commands or parallelize work outside the event loop, useful for CPU-bound tasks or integrating native tools.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Parallel work
â€¢ Running external tools
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Image processing with native binaries
â€¢ Running build tools

questions.title: What is spawn(), exec(), and fork()?
questions.answer: spawn launches a process with a stream-based interface, exec runs a command and buffers output (good for small outputs), and fork spawns a new Node process with IPC channel for communication. Choose based on streaming needs and IPC requirements.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Streaming child outputs
â€¢ Worker processes

questions.title: What is the OS module?
questions.answer: The OS module provides utilities to query system information (CPU, memory, platform) and interacts with OS-level details to make runtime decisions.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Choosing worker counts
â€¢ Health checks

questions.title: What is the Cluster module?
questions.answer: The Cluster module enables launching worker processes that share server ports, providing a simple way to scale across CPU cores with a master/worker model.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Vertical scaling
â€¢ Worker supervision
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Multi-core servers
â€¢ Crash isolation

questions.title: What is the Net module?
questions.answer: The Net module provides low-level TCP/IPC networking primitives for building custom protocol servers and clients.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ TCP servers
â€¢ Custom protocols
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Proxy servers
â€¢ Custom protocol handlers

questions.title: What is the DNS module?
questions.answer: The DNS module provides name resolution APIs (lookup, resolve) to resolve hostnames to IPs and query DNS records from Node code.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Service discovery
â€¢ Custom resolution
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Dynamic host lookup
â€¢ Custom DNS queries

questions.title: What is the HTTP module?
questions.answer: The HTTP module implements core HTTP server/client functionality. Frameworks like Express build on top of it; using it directly gives maximum control and minimal overhead.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Lightweight servers
â€¢ Custom handling
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Proxy servers
â€¢ Custom header handling

questions.title: What is the HTTPS module?
questions.answer: The HTTPS module wraps HTTP with TLS, enabling secure servers and clients when provided with certificates and keys.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Secure servers
â€¢ TLS termination
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Secure APIs
â€¢ Mutual TLS

questions.title: What is middleware chaining in Express?
questions.answer: Middleware chaining composes multiple middleware functions that call next() to pass control to the next handler, enabling layered concerns like auth, validation, and logging.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Composability
â€¢ Separation of concerns
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Auth pipelines
â€¢ Request validation

questions.title: What are Guards (in NestJS)?
questions.answer: Guards are NestJS constructs that determine whether a request should be handled, similar to middleware but integrated with NestJS's DI and metadata system for role checks and auth.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Role checks
â€¢ Permission gating

questions.title: What is the difference between PUT and PATCH?
questions.answer: PUT replaces a resource with the provided payload (idempotent), while PATCH applies partial modifications (non-replacing), making PATCH suitable for partial updates.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Update user profile
â€¢ Partial resource edits

questions.title: What is the difference between 400, 401, 403, 404, 500 HTTP status codes?
questions.answer: 400 = Bad Request (invalid input), 401 = Unauthorized (authentication required/invalid), 403 = Forbidden (no permissions), 404 = Not Found (resource missing), 500 = Internal Server Error (server-side failure). Use correct codes to aid clients and observability.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ API error handling
â€¢ Client guidance
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Validation errors
â€¢ Auth failures

questions.title: What is API versioning?
questions.answer: API versioning manages changes to an API contract using URL/version header negotiation, or content negotiation, enabling backward compatibility while evolving endpoints.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Backward compatibility
â€¢ Safe evolution
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ v1/v2 endpoints
â€¢ Header-based versions

questions.title: What is reverse proxying?
questions.answer: Reverse proxying routes requests from clients to backend servers, providing TLS termination, caching, and load balancing, and hiding internal topology.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ NGINX in front of Node
â€¢ CDN origins

questions.title: What is Backpressure in Streams?
questions.answer: Backpressure is a flow-control mechanism where readable streams respect the consumer's ability to process data; writable streams signal when to pause/resume, preventing memory overflow and ensuring stable throughput.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Throttling fast producers
â€¢ Stable pipeline processing

questions.title: What is Chunked Transfer Encoding?
questions.answer: Chunked transfer encoding sends HTTP responses in pieces (chunks) without a predefined Content-Length, allowing streaming of dynamically generated content.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Streaming responses
â€¢ Progressive rendering
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Large file streaming
â€¢ Server push

questions.title: What is Caching Strategy: TTL, LRU?
questions.answer: TTL (Time-To-Live) expires entries after a period; LRU (Least Recently Used) evicts least-accessed entries when full. Choose strategies based on data volatility and access patterns.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Cache eviction
â€¢ Freshness control
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Session caches
â€¢ Query result caching

questions.title: What is the difference between Monolith and Microservices?
questions.answer: A monolith bundles functionality in a single deployable unit; microservices split functionality into smaller, independent services. Microservices improve modularity and scaling but increase operational complexity.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Architecture decisions
â€¢ Scaling strategies
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Legacy monolith migration
â€¢ Domain decomposition

questions.title: What is Database Sharding?
questions.answer: Sharding splits a database horizontally across multiple servers so each shard holds a subset of data, improving write scalability and reducing single-node load.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Scaling writes
â€¢ Horizontal partitioning
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ User-based sharding
â€¢ Geo-based shards

questions.title: What is Read Replicas?
questions.answer: Read replicas are copies of a primary database used to serve read-heavy traffic, offloading queries from the master and improving read scalability.
