questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Analytics queries
â€¢ Reporting endpoints

questions.title: What is Connection Pooling in Node.js?
questions.answer: Connection pooling reuses database connections from a pool to reduce overhead of creating new connections, improving performance and resource usage.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ DB efficiency
â€¢ Resource management
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ High-concurrency DB access
â€¢ API backends

questions.title: What is server-side rendering (SSR) with Node.js?
questions.answer: SSR renders HTML on the server before sending it to clients, improving initial load performance and SEO; Node can render apps (e.g., React) server-side and stream content progressively.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ SEO
â€¢ Faster first paint
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Universal React apps
â€¢ Landing pages

questions.title: What is JWT signature verification?
questions.answer: JWT signature verification checks the token's signature using a secret or public key to ensure integrity and authenticity of claims before trusting the token data.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Auth security
â€¢ Claim validation
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Token validation middleware
â€¢ API auth

questions.title: What is Bcrypt hashing?
questions.answer: Bcrypt is a password hashing function that uses adaptive work factors and salt to make brute-force attacks computationally expensive; use it to store passwords securely.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Password storage
â€¢ Credential protection
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ User account storage
â€¢ Auth services

questions.title: What is ETag and caching headers?
questions.answer: ETag is a response identifier used to validate caches; caching headers (Cache-Control, Expires) control client and intermediary caching behavior to reduce bandwidth and improve performance.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Cache validation
â€¢ Bandwidth optimization
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Conditional requests
â€¢ CDN caching

questions.title: What is Circuit Breaker Pattern?
questions.answer: Circuit Breaker prevents cascading failures by stopping calls to failing services after a threshold, allowing systems to recover and fall back gracefully.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Protecting downstream APIs
â€¢ Retry throttling

questions.title: What is Retry Pattern?
questions.answer: Retry pattern retries transient failures with backoff (exponential jitter) to improve robustness; combine with idempotency and circuit breakers to avoid overload.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Transient fault handling
â€¢ Robustness
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Retrying HTTP calls
â€¢ DB transient errors

questions.title: What is Debouncing and Throttling in Node.js?
questions.answer: Debouncing delays a function until a quiet period ends, while throttling ensures a function runs at most once per interval. Both control event frequency to improve performance.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Event handling
â€¢ Rate control
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Search input
â€¢ Resize events

questions.title: What is Load Testing?
questions.answer: Load testing measures system behavior under expected and peak traffic to find bottlenecks, using tools to simulate concurrent users and measure latency, throughput, and errors.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Capacity planning
â€¢ Performance validation
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Pre-release stress tests
â€¢ SLA verification

questions.title: Tools for Load Testing (k6, JMeter, Artillery).
questions.answer: k6 is a modern JS-based load tool, JMeter is a mature Java-based tool, and Artillery is lightweight and easy to use with Node; choose based on scale, scripting needs, and CI integration.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Performance tools
â€¢ CI integration
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ CI load checks
â€¢ Stress testing

questions.title: What is GraphQL with Node.js?
questions.answer: GraphQL is a query language and runtime for APIs allowing clients to request exactly the data they need. Using Node with libraries like Apollo Server or graphql-js enables building typed, efficient APIs with single endpoint and schema-driven contracts.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Flexible APIs
â€¢ Single endpoint
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Mobile-optimized queries
â€¢ Schema evolution

questions.title: What is Prisma ORM?
questions.answer: Prisma is a modern ORM providing a type-safe query API and schema-based migrations; it improves developer ergonomics and integrates well with TypeScript.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Typed DB access
â€¢ Migrations
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Type-safe queries
â€¢ Auto-generated clients

questions.title: What is Sequelize ORM?
questions.answer: Sequelize is a promise-based Node ORM for SQL databases offering model definitions, relations, and migrations; it's mature and widely used for relational DBs.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ SQL ORM
â€¢ Model mapping
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ CRUD services
â€¢ Legacy projects

questions.title: What is Mongoose?
questions.answer: Mongoose is an ODM for MongoDB providing schema, validation, and middleware hooks to model MongoDB documents in Node applications.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ User profiles
â€¢ Document stores

questions.title: What is ACID in databases?
questions.answer: ACID stands for Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durabilityâ€”properties that guarantee reliable transaction processing in relational databases.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Transactional integrity
â€¢ Financial systems
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Banking transactions
â€¢ Order processing

questions.title: What is CAP theorem?
questions.answer: CAP theorem states a distributed system can guarantee at most two of Consistency, Availability, and Partition tolerance; trade-offs guide design depending on application priorities.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Distributed design
â€¢ Consistency models
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Eventual consistency choices
â€¢ Partition-tolerant services

questions.title: What is Event Sourcing Architecture?
questions.answer: Event Sourcing persists state changes as an immutable sequence of events; the current state is derived by replaying events. It enables auditability, temporal queries, and easier reasoning about state changes.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Audit logs
â€¢ Temporal queries
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Financial ledgers
â€¢ Audit trails

questions.title: What is CQRS pattern?
questions.answer: CQRS separates read and write models: commands mutate state while queries read optimized projections. It allows independent scaling and optimization of reads and writes.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Scaling reads/writes
â€¢ Complex domains
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ High-read services
â€¢ Reporting projections

questions.title: What is Zero Downtime Deployment?
questions.answer: Zero-downtime deploys update services without interrupting traffic using strategies like rolling updates, blue/green, or canary releases with health checks and load balancer orchestration.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ High availability
â€¢ Safe releases
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Rolling updates in Kubernetes
â€¢ Canary deployments

questions.title: What is graceful shutdown in Node.js?
questions.answer: Graceful shutdown lets servers finish inflight requests, close resources, and exit cleanly on signals (SIGINT/SIGTERM), preventing data loss and improving reliability during restarts.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Deployment safety
â€¢ Resource cleanup
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Handling SIGTERM in containers
â€¢ Draining connections

questions.title: What is Heap Memory in Node.js?
questions.answer: Heap memory is where JS objects are allocated in V8; monitoring heap usage helps detect memory leaks and tune V8 flags for performance.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Memory profiling
â€¢ Leak detection
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Heap snapshots
â€¢ Memory thresholds

questions.title: What is Garbage Collection in V8?
questions.answer: V8 performs automatic garbage collection to reclaim unused memory via generational collectors and compaction; tuning flags can influence GC behavior and pause times.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Memory management
â€¢ Performance tuning
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Reducing GC pauses
â€¢ Optimizing long-running services

questions.title: What is Memory Leak in Node.js?
questions.answer: A memory leak occurs when objects are unintentionally retained, preventing GC from freeing memory; common causes include global references, unbounded caches, and event listener leaks.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Fixing long-running service leaks
â€¢ Identifying retained closures

questions.title: What is Hot Reloading (Nodemon)?
questions.answer: Nodemon watches files and restarts the Node process on changes, speeding developer feedback loops; hot module replacement is a more advanced technique to swap modules without full restarts.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Developer productivity
â€¢ Rapid iteration
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Auto-restart dev servers
â€¢ Faster local testing

questions.title: What is Cold Start?
questions.answer: Cold start is the initial startup latency when a serverless function or process boots and initializes dependencies; minimizing cold start improves responsiveness for rarely-invoked functions.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Serverless optimization
â€¢ Latency reduction
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ AWS Lambda warmers
â€¢ Provisioned concurrency

questions.title: What is Serverless with Node.js?
questions.answer: Serverless runs functions on-demand without infrastructure management; Node is a popular runtime for serverless functions offering fast startup and concise handlers for APIs and event processing.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Event-driven processing
â€¢ Cost-effective scaling
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ AWS Lambda APIs
â€¢ Event-driven jobs

questions.title: What are AWS Lambda, API Gateway, DynamoDB integrations with Node.js?
questions.answer: These AWS services combine to build serverless APIs: API Gateway routes HTTP traffic to Lambda functions written in Node; Lambda handles logic; DynamoDB stores data in a scalable NoSQL table.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Serverless APIs
â€¢ Event-driven apps
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Webhook handlers
â€¢ Serverless backends

questions.title: What is message acknowledgment in queues?
questions.answer: Message acknowledgment confirms successful processing to the broker, allowing it to remove messages; lack of ack often triggers redelivery and helps ensure at-least-once or exactly-once semantics depending on broker and design.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Reliable processing
â€¢ Exactly-once patterns
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Order processing
â€¢ Retry handling

questions.title: What is Cron Job in Node.js?
questions.answer: Cron jobs schedule recurring tasks; libraries like node-cron allow defining cron expressions to run jobs at intervals for maintenance, reporting, or cleanup.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Daily reports
â€¢ Cache cleanup

questions.title: What is node-cron?
questions.answer: node-cron is a lightweight scheduler for running cron-style jobs in Node; it's useful for local scheduled tasks but not a replacement for distributed schedulers in production.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Local scheduling
â€¢ Dev tools
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Periodic reports
â€¢ Housekeeping

questions.title: What is Webhook?
questions.answer: A webhook is an HTTP callback where a service posts events to a configured URL; webhooks enable event-driven integrations between systems.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Payment notifications
â€¢ Third-party integrations

questions.title: What is OAuth2 authorization?
questions.answer: OAuth2 is an authorization framework allowing third-party applications to obtain limited access on behalf of users via tokens and defined flows (authorization code, client credentials). It standardizes delegated authorization.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Third-party access
â€¢ APIs auth
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Login with Google
â€¢ Service-to-service tokens

questions.title: What is SSO (Single Sign-On)?
questions.answer: SSO allows users to authenticate once and access multiple services without reauthenticating by sharing trust via tokens or federated identity protocols (SAML, OAuth/OIDC).
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Unified auth
â€¢ User convenience
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Enterprise portals
â€¢ Integrated apps

questions.title: What is Express.js?
questions.answer: Express.js is a minimal, unopinionated web framework for Node.js that provides routing, middleware support, and utilities to build REST APIs and server-side applications quickly. It's the industry standard for Node backend development.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ REST APIs
â€¢ Web servers
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ eCommerce backends
â€¢ Microservices

questions.title: Why do we use Express.js in Node applications?
questions.answer: Express provides a lightweight abstraction over Node's HTTP module, simplifying routing, middleware management, and request/response handling. It reduces boilerplate code and enables rapid development of scalable APIs.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Fast API development
â€¢ Code organization
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Startup MVPs
â€¢ Enterprise APIs

questions.title: What are middleware functions in Express.js?
questions.answer: Middleware functions are reusable code that sits between request and response. They can modify requests/responses, handle authentication, logging, validation, or perform business logic. Middleware is chained using next() to pass control to the next handler.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Auth checks
â€¢ Request logging
â€¢ Data validation
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ JWT verification
â€¢ Request body parsing

questions.title: What is the role of app.use() in Express?
questions.answer: app.use() mounts middleware or routers at a specified path. It applies middleware globally to all routes or conditionally to specific path prefixes. Example: app.use('/api', apiRouter) mounts the apiRouter for all /api/* routes.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Mounting routers
â€¢ Global middleware
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ API versioning
â€¢ /api/v1 routing

questions.title: What is the difference between app.get() and app.post()?
questions.answer: app.get() handles HTTP GET requests (fetch data without side effects), while app.post() handles POST requests (send data with side effects). GET requests should be idempotent; POST requests create/modify resources.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Fetching data
â€¢ Creating resources
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Product listing
â€¢ User registration

questions.title: What is Express Router and why is it used?
questions.answer: Express Router is a mini Express application that handles routing independently. It allows modular route organization by grouping related routes (e.g., user routes, product routes) and mounting them on the main app, improving code maintainability and scalability.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Modular routing
â€¢ Namespace isolation
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ User routes (/users)
â€¢ Product routes (/products)

questions.title: How do you create modular routes in Express.js?
questions.answer: Create separate router files using express.Router(), define routes within them, then mount them on the main app using app.use(). Example: const userRouter = express.Router(); userRouter.get('/:id'); app.use('/users', userRouter);
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Scalable architecture
â€¢ Code reuse
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Large eCommerce projects
â€¢ Multi-domain apps

questions.title: What is the requestâ€“response cycle in Express?
questions.answer: The cycle flows: Request â†’ Express receives â†’ Routing â†’ Middleware chain (each calls next()) â†’ Route handler â†’ Response sent. Once res.send/json/end is called, the cycle completes. Calling next() after send causes error.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Middleware chaining
â€¢ Error handling

questions.title: What is the purpose of next() in middleware?
questions.answer: next() passes control to the next middleware or route handler in the chain. If not called, the request hangs. Calling next(error) skips to error-handling middleware. Each middleware must call next() or send a response.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Middleware chaining
â€¢ Flow control
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Auth checks
â€¢ Logging before handlers

questions.title: What is error-handling middleware in Express.js?
questions.answer: Error-handling middleware has 4 parameters (err, req, res, next) instead of 3. It catches errors thrown in route handlers or other middleware. Must be mounted AFTER all other app.use/routes. Called via next(error).
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Global error handling
â€¢ Centralized logging
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Catching 404s
â€¢ Validating input errors

questions.title: What is the difference between application-level and router-level middleware?
questions.answer: Application-level middleware applies globally using app.use(); router-level middleware applies only to specific routers using router.use(). Router-level middleware provides isolation and namespace control for modular applications.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ CORS for all vs specific routes

questions.title: How do you handle CORS in Express.js?
questions.answer: Use the cors package: npm install cors, then app.use(cors()) for all origins or app.use(cors({origin: 'https://example.com'})) for specific origins. Set allowed methods, headers, and credentials to control cross-origin requests.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Frontend-backend communication
â€¢ Public APIs
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ React frontend on different port
â€¢ Third-party integrations

questions.title: How do you serve static files in Express.js?
questions.answer: Use app.use(express.static('public')) to serve files from the 'public' directory. Files are accessible at http://localhost:3000/filename. Configure multiple dirs: app.use(express.static('public')); app.use(express.static('uploads'));
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Product images
â€¢ PDFs, CSVs

questions.title: What are the different ways to handle authentication in Express?
questions.answer: Session-based (req.session), JWT (Bearer tokens), API keys, OAuth2, Basic Auth. JWT is stateless and scalable; sessions require server memory. Each has trade-offs in security, scalability, and complexity.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Login endpoints
â€¢ Protected routes

questions.title: How do you secure Express apps using Helmet.js?
questions.answer: Install Helmet: npm install helmet, then app.use(helmet()). It sets security HTTP headers (X-Frame-Options, CSP, HSTS, etc.) to prevent clickjacking, XSS, MIME sniffing, and other attacks.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Production APIs

questions.title: What is the difference between res.send() and res.json()?
questions.answer: res.send() sends a string or HTML; res.json() sends JSON with Content-Type: application/json header and automatically stringifies objects. Use res.json() for APIs; res.send() for mixed content.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ API responses
â€¢ Mixed content
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ REST endpoints
â€¢ HTML templates

questions.title: How do you implement JWT authentication in Express.js?
questions.answer: Create tokens with jwt.sign(payload, secret) on login; verify with jwt.verify() in middleware. Store secret in env vars. Tokens sent as Bearer in Authorization header. Middleware extracts & verifies before handler execution.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Login/logout flows
â€¢ Protected routes

questions.title: How do you protect routes using middleware in Express?
questions.answer: Create auth middleware: const auth = (req, res, next) => { verify JWT; if valid next(); else res.status(401).json(...) }. Mount on routes: router.get('/admin', auth, handler). Middleware blocks unauthorized access.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Admin routes
â€¢ User profiles

questions.title: What is the purpose of express.json() and express.urlencoded()?
questions.answer: express.json() parses JSON request bodies; express.urlencoded() parses form data. Both are middleware: app.use(express.json()); app.use(express.urlencoded({extended:true})). Required to access req.body in handlers.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ POST/PUT endpoints

questions.title: How do you handle file uploads in Express.js?
questions.answer: Use Multer middleware: const upload = multer({dest: 'uploads/'}); app.post('/upload', upload.single('file'), handler). Multer parses multipart/form-data, stores files, and populates req.file with metadata.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ File handling
â€¢ Image uploads
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Product images
â€¢ User avatars

questions.title: What is Multer and why is it used?
questions.answer: Multer is Node.js middleware for handling file uploads. It parses multipart/form-data, stores files to disk or memory, and provides file metadata (name, size, MIME type). Essential for eCommerce product images and documents.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ File uploads
â€¢ Image storage
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Bulk product imports
â€¢ User profile pictures

questions.title: What is the meaning of 'Cannot set headers after they are sent'?
questions.answer: This error occurs when code tries to set headers (res.setHeader, res.status, res.redirect) AFTER res.send/json/end is called. Once response headers are sent, they cannot be modified. Fix by ensuring only one response method per request.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Error handling

questions.title: How do you implement API versioning in Express?
questions.answer: URL versioning: app.use('/api/v1', v1Routes); app.use('/api/v2', v2Routes). Header versioning: check req.header('api-version'). URL is preferred for clarity and caching. Allows backward compatibility during API evolution.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Multiple API versions

questions.title: What are best practices for structuring an Express.js application?
questions.answer: Use MVC: models/, controllers/, routes/, services/. Separate concerns: business logic in services, database in models, request handling in controllers. Use routers for modular routes. Env-based config. Clear error handling. Follow DRY principle.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Large projects

questions.title: How do you connect Express.js to a database (MongoDB/SQL)?
questions.answer: For MongoDB: mongoose.connect(uri). For SQL: create connection pool using mysql2, pg, or oracle client. Store connection string in env vars. Wrap in try-catch for error handling. Use DAOs/models to abstract database logic.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ eCommerce backends

questions.title: What is the difference between synchronous and asynchronous middleware?
questions.answer: Sync middleware executes immediately; async middleware uses async/await or promises. Async: async (req, res, next) => { await dbCall(); next(); }. Error in async caught by error handler if next(error) called. Always use async for I/O.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Database queries

questions.title: How do you handle global exceptions in Express.js?
questions.answer: Use error-handling middleware (4 params) mounted LAST: app.use((err, req, res, next) => { res.status(err.status || 500).json({error: err.message}) }). Wrap route handlers in try-catch; call next(error) to trigger error handler.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Production logging

questions.title: How do you implement rate limiting in Express.js?
questions.answer: Use express-rate-limit: const limiter = rateLimit({windowMs: 15*60*1000, max: 100}); app.use(limiter). Tracks IP and limits requests per window. Configure store (memory, Redis) for distributed systems. Protect /login, /api endpoints.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ DDoS protection
â€¢ Abuse prevention
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Login throttling
â€¢ API quotas

questions.title: How do you use Morgan for logging in Express?
questions.answer: npm install morgan; app.use(morgan('combined')). Logs HTTP requests with method, URL, status, response time. Use 'dev' for development (colored), 'combined' for production. Pipe logs to files for persistence.
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Debugging
â€¢ Analytics

questions.title: What is clustering in Node.js and how does Express support it?
questions.answer: Clustering spawns multiple Express processes (workers) across CPU cores, sharing a server port via a master process. Use Node cluster module or PM2. Improves throughput by handling requests in parallel on multi-core machines.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Production servers

questions.title: How do you design RESTful APIs using Express.js in a scalable microservices architecture?
questions.answer: Each microservice is an Express app with clear responsibility (users, orders, payments). Use HTTP + JSON for communication. API Gateway routes client requests to services. Implement service discovery, load balancing. Use JWT for inter-service auth.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ eCommerce platform

questions.title: How do you structure controllers, services, and routes for large Express.js projects?
questions.answer: Routes: define endpoints (GET /users). Controllers: handle req/res, call services. Services: business logic, database calls, external APIs. Models: database schemas. This separation enables testing, scalability, and code reuse.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Enterprise apps

questions.title: How do you implement global error handling in Express for REST APIs?
questions.answer: Create custom error classes (ValidationError, NotFoundError). Throw in handlers; catch in middleware. Error middleware logs, formats response with HTTP status and message. Ensures consistent error responses across all endpoints.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ API consistency

questions.title: How do you implement versioning in Express REST APIs for backward compatibility?
questions.answer: URL versioning: /api/v1/users, /api/v2/users. Header versioning: API-Version header. Maintain old versions alongside new. Update clients gradually. New version can coexist with old; ensures no breaking changes.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Client migration

questions.title: How do you secure REST APIs in Express using middleware and JWT?
questions.answer: Auth middleware: extract token from Authorization header, verify JWT using secret, attach user to req. Protect routes: app.post('/orders', auth, createOrder). Validate scopes/roles for authorization. Use HTTPS in production.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Protected endpoints

questions.title: How do you validate incoming API request payloads in Express.js?
questions.answer: Use Joi, Zod, or express-validator. Define schemas: const schema = Joi.object({email, password}). Validate: const {error, value} = schema.validate(req.body). Return 400 if invalid. Prevents malformed data and SQL injection.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ User registration

questions.title: How do you optimize Express.js API performance under high traffic?
questions.answer: Use caching (Redis), pagination for large datasets, index databases, compress responses (gzip), use CDN for static files, implement rate limiting, async processing (queues). Monitor with APM tools. Horizontal scaling with load balancers.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Black Friday sales

questions.title: How do you handle rate limiting and throttling in Express.js APIs?
questions.answer: Rate limiting: limit requests per IP per time window (express-rate-limit). Throttling: delay/defer requests to smooth load. Combine both: limit first, then throttle for burst handling. Use Redis for distributed rate limiting.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Flash sales

questions.title: How do you implement pagination, filtering, and sorting in REST APIs?
questions.answer: Pagination: skip, limit query params. Filtering: match on fields (req.query.status). Sorting: sort param (asc/desc). Query: db.find({status}).skip(skip).limit(limit).sort({createdAt: -1}). Reduces response size and improves performance.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Product listing

questions.title: How do you perform schema validation for REST requests using JOI/Zod?
questions.answer: Joi: const schema = Joi.object({email: Joi.string().email()}). Zod: const schema = z.object({email: z.string().email()}). Validate: schema.validate(data). Use as middleware. Provides type safety and detailed error messages.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Type safety

questions.title: How do you implement JWT authentication in Express.js?
questions.answer: On login: create token with jwt.sign({userId, role}, SECRET, {expiresIn: '1h'}). Return token to client. On request: extract from Authorization header; verify with jwt.verify(token, SECRET). Decode for userId/role. Error if expired or invalid.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Login/protected routes

questions.title: How do you design a refresh token flow in Express for long-lived sessions?
questions.answer: Issue short-lived access token (1h) and long-lived refresh token (7d). Store refresh token in db/cookie. On expiry: client sends refresh token; server validates, issues new access token. Logout: invalidate refresh token in db.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Mobile apps

questions.title: How do you implement role-based access control (RBAC) using JWT claims?
questions.answer: Encode role in JWT: jwt.sign({userId, role: 'admin'}, SECRET). Middleware checks role: if(req.user.role !== 'admin') return 401. Protect routes by role. Combine with db checks for dynamic permissions.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Admin vs customer routes

questions.title: How do you secure JWT storage on the frontend using Axios?
questions.answer: Store token in httpOnly cookie (secure, sameSite) set by server. Avoid localStorage (XSS risk). Axios interceptor auto-includes cookie. Alternative: sessionStorage + manual header injection if using custom storage. Always use HTTPS.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ React apps

questions.title: How do you handle JWT expiry and silent token refresh in React + Axios?
questions.answer: Axios interceptor detects 401. Call refresh endpoint to get new token. Retry original request. Store tokens securely. Handle refresh failures by redirecting to login. Implement exponential backoff to avoid infinite loops.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Seamless UX

questions.title: How do you invalidate JWT tokens during logout in a microservices setup?
questions.answer: JWTs are stateless; invalidation requires a blacklist (db/Redis) or token revocation endpoint. Store token jti in blacklist on logout. Middleware checks blacklist. Alternative: short expiry + refresh token rotation; invalidate refresh on logout.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Immediate logout

questions.title: How do you manage permissions for CUSTOMER vs ADMIN roles in your eCommerce project?
questions.answer: Encode role in JWT. Customers: view products, place orders, view orders. Admins: manage products, orders, users, promotions. Use role-based middleware on routes. DB checks for additional permission validation. Log privileged actions.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Portal separation

questions.title: How do you protect internal microservice-to-microservice communication with JWT?
questions.answer: Each service has a service account with JWT credentials. Services verify tokens from other services using shared secret or public key. Implement rate limiting between services. Use service discovery for endpoint resolution.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Service calls

questions.title: How do you configure Axios interceptors for JWT injection in React apps?
questions.answer: axios.interceptors.request.use((config) => { config.headers.Authorization = 'Bearer ' + token; return config; }). Response interceptor handles 401 by refreshing token. Error interceptor logs/notifies user. Centralize in axiosInstance.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ API auth

questions.title: How do you handle global error handling for API failures using Axios?
questions.answer: Response interceptor catches all errors: (error) => { if (error.response.status === 401) logout(); else toast(error.message); }. Request interceptor retries on network errors. Handle network failures vs API errors differently.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ User feedback

questions.title: How do you implement API retries and exponential backoff using Axios?
questions.answer: Interceptor retries on 5xx/network errors. Exponential backoff: delay = base * (2 ^ retryCount). Stop after max retries. Libraries: axios-retry. Prevents cascading failures; improves reliability.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Transient failures

questions.title: How do you design Axios-based service-layer architecture to communicate with multiple microservices?
questions.answer: Create API clients per service: userService.get(id), orderService.create(). Each client configures endpoint + auth. Centralize interceptors (auth, errors, retries). Abstract HTTP layer from components. Enables easy service endpoint changes.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ eCommerce app

questions.title: How do you secure Axios requests against XSS and CSRF attacks?
questions.answer: XSS: sanitize inputs, use Content Security Policy. CSRF: backend sends CSRF token; Axios auto-includes in header. Use sameSite cookies. Store tokens securely (httpOnly). Never eval() or innerHTML with user data.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Production apps

questions.title: How do you implement Redis caching for frequently accessed eCommerce APIs?
questions.answer: On product GET: check Redis; if hit, return. If miss, query DB, cache with TTL (15min), return. On product update: invalidate cache. Use cache patterns: cache-aside, write-through. Reduces DB load, improves response time.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Product pages

questions.title: What caching strategy do you use for product details and category listing?
questions.answer: Cache-aside for product details: check Redis > DB > cache result. TTL: 1 hour. Invalidate on update. Category listing: cache longer (24h) as less volatile. Use tags/patterns for batch invalidation. Monitor cache hit ratio.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ eCommerce

questions.title: How do you design cache invalidation strategies in a microservices ecosystem?
questions.answer: Event-driven: when order service updates, publish event. Cache service listens, invalidates related caches. TTL-based: expire entries periodically. Dependency tracking: cache interdependencies. Prevents stale data across services.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Multiple services

questions.title: How do you implement in-memory caching vs distributed caching in Express.js?
questions.answer: In-memory: Map/object, fast, single instance only. Distributed: Redis/Memcached, shared across instances, slower but consistent. Single instance: in-memory. Multiple instances: Redis. Hybrid: in-memory for local, Redis for shared.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Scaling

questions.title: How do you reduce database calls in high-traffic eCommerce APIs using caching layers?
questions.answer: Multi-layer: browser cache > CDN > app cache (Redis) > db. Cache products, categories, user profiles. Invalidate on updates. Monitor cache effectiveness. Combine with pagination, indexing, denormalization for optimal performance.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Peak traffic

questions.title: How do you optimize bulk reads/writes in Express.js using caching layers?
questions.answer: Batch reads: use IN queries. Cache aggregated results. Batch writes: bulk insert to DB, then update cache. Use write-through cache (write to DB, then cache). Message queue for async bulk operations.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Batch imports

questions.title: How do you identify and fix bottlenecks in Express using profiling tools?
questions.answer: Use clinic.js, autocannon for load testing. Profile CPU: node --prof. Identify hot functions. Monitor memory leaks. Check database query performance (EXPLAIN plans). Use APM (New Relic, DataDog). Optimize or cache slow paths.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Optimization

questions.title: How do you establish and manage SQL (Oracle/PostgreSQL/MySQL) DB connections from Express?
questions.answer: Create connection pool: const pool = mysql.createPool({connectionLimit, host, user}). On route: pool.getConnection((err, conn) => { conn.query(sql, (err, rows) => { conn.release(); }); }). Reuse connections; avoid recreating.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ SQL integration

questions.title: How do you implement connection pooling for SQL databases in Node.js?
questions.answer: Connection pool: mysql.createPool({connectionLimit: 10, host, user, password, database}). Maintains 10 persistent connections. On query, lease from pool; return after use. Reduces connection overhead, enables concurrent queries.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ High concurrency

questions.title: How do you avoid SQL injection attacks in Express.js applications?
questions.answer: Use parameterized queries: pool.query('SELECT * FROM users WHERE id = ?', [userId]). Never concatenate user input. Use ORMs (Sequelize, Prisma) which auto-escape. Validate/sanitize inputs on backend.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Database queries

questions.title: How do you write optimized SQL queries for high-volume order/order-item transactions?
questions.answer: Use indexes on foreign keys, timestamps. Batch inserts: INSERT INTO orders VALUES (...), (...) for bulk. Join order + order_items efficiently. Use EXPLAIN to analyze. Denormalize for reads. Archive old orders.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Black Friday

questions.title: How do you handle transactions (commit & rollback) in Node.js SQL clients?
questions.answer: conn.beginTransaction(); do work; if success conn.commit(); else conn.rollback(). Ensures atomicity: all or nothing. Use for order + payment: if payment fails, rollback entire order creation. Essential for data consistency.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Order processing

questions.title: How do you model relational data (Users, Orders, Payments) in Oracle SQL for eCommerce?
questions.answer: Users table: id, email, password. Orders table: id, userId (FK), total, status. OrderItems table: id, orderId (FK), productId, quantity. Payments table: id, orderId (FK), amount, status. Normalize to reduce redundancy; use FKs for integrity.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ eCommerce DB

questions.title: How do you implement stored procedures for performance optimization?
questions.answer: Stored procedure: CREATE PROCEDURE getOrderDetails(orderId IN NUMBER) AS SELECT * FROM orders WHERE id = orderId. Call from Express: conn.execute('BEGIN getOrderDetails(:1); END;', [id]). Reduces network round-trips.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Complex logic

questions.title: When do you choose MongoDB over SQL in an eCommerce architecture?
questions.answer: MongoDB: flexible schema (variants, attributes), rapid prototyping, unstructured data (reviews, ratings). SQL: relational data (users, orders, payments), transactions, ACID. Hybrid: MongoDB for catalog, SQL for orders/payments.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ eCommerce design

questions.title: How do you manage connections and pool settings for MongoDB in Express?
questions.answer: mongoose.connect(uri, {maxPoolSize: 10, minPoolSize: 5}). Connection pool auto-managed. Reuse connection; don't create per request. Monitor pool stats. Set serverSelectionTimeoutMS for failover.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Production

questions.title: How do you design flexible product or catalog schema using MongoDB?
questions.answer: Product doc: {id, name, category, price, specs: {color, size} (array)}. Variants as sub-documents. Flexible: add fields without migration. Indexing: category, price for queries. Trade-off: flexibility vs query complexity.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Product catalog

questions.title: How do you handle complex aggregations using MongoDB aggregation pipelines?
questions.answer: $match â†’ filter, $group â†’ aggregate (sum, count), $sort â†’ order, $limit â†’ paginate. Example: db.orders.aggregate([{$match: {status: 'completed'}}, {$group: {_id: '$userId', total: {$sum: '$amount'}}}]).
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Reports

questions.title: How do you index MongoDB collections for high read/write performance?
questions.answer: Create indexes: db.products.createIndex({name: 1}), compound: {category: 1, price: 1}. Monitor slow queries. Remove unused indexes. Indexing speeds reads but slows writes. Balance for use case.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Query optimization

questions.title: How do you prevent performance degradation due to unbounded document growth?
questions.answer: Use arrays with limits: reviews: [{...}].slice(-100) keep last 100. Archive old data to separate collection. Denormalize summary fields. Monitor document size. Cap collections limit growth.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Growing data

questions.title: How do you model cart, wishlist, or product variants using MongoDB?
questions.answer: Cart: {userId, items: [{productId, variant: {color, size}, qty}]}. Wishlist: {userId, products: [productId]}. Variants: stored in product doc or separate collection. Denormalize for performance; invalidate cache on changes.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ eCommerce

questions.title: How do you split an eCommerce monolith into Express microservices?
questions.answer: Extract by domain: User Service, Product Service, Order Service, Payment Service. Each service: independent codebase, DB, Express app. API Gateway routes /users to User Service, /products to Product Service. Communicate via HTTP/events.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Scaling

questions.title: How do microservices authenticate requests using JWT tokens?
questions.answer: Auth Service issues JWT. API Gateway verifies and injects user into req. Other services verify using shared secret. JWT includes userId, role. Services trust JWT; don't re-validate. Symmetric (secret) or asymmetric (public key) signing.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Service communication

questions.title: How do you design API Gateway + BFF architecture for React clients?
questions.answer: API Gateway: single entry point, routes to microservices, handles auth, rate limiting, logging. BFF (Backend-for-Frontend): aggregates data from multiple services for React. Reduces client-side logic, improves performance.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Client-server

questions.title: How do you handle inter-service communication in Express microservices?
questions.answer: Synchronous: HTTP REST or gRPC. Service A calls Service B. Order Service calls Payment Service. Asynchronous: message queues (Kafka, RabbitMQ). Service publishes event; other services consume. Async preferred for loose coupling.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Order flow

questions.title: How do you prevent duplicated logic across services (DRY pattern)?
questions.answer: Shared library: npm package with utils, validators, constants. Auth logic in shared lib. Services import and use. Reduces duplication. Version carefully; semver versioning. Alternatively, shared service (Auth Service) for cross-cutting concerns.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Consistency

questions.title: How do you handle distributed logging and tracing in microservices?
questions.answer: Log aggregation: ELK (Elasticsearch, Logstash, Kibana) or Splunk. Distributed tracing: Jaeger, Zipkin. Inject trace ID into all logs. Correlate logs across services via trace ID. Monitor latency end-to-end.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Debugging

questions.title: How do you ensure eventual consistency across microservices?
questions.answer: Event-driven: order created â†’ publish event. Inventory Service consumes, updates stock eventually. If Inventory Service fails, event replayed later. Saga pattern: chain service calls; compensate on failure (refund if inventory insufficient).
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Distributed transactions

questions.title: How do you version independent microservices without breaking clients?
questions.answer: API versioning: /v1/products, /v2/products. Support multiple versions simultaneously. Clients migrate gradually. Deprecate old versions after notice period. Backward-compatible changes don't need versioning.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Updates

questions.title: How do you handle failures gracefully using circuit breakers or retries?
questions.answer: Circuit Breaker: after N failures, open circuit; fail fast, prevent cascades. Retry: exponential backoff, max retries. Libraries: node-resilience, axios-retry. Fallback: return cached data or default response if service down.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ High availability

questions.title: How do you integrate Express.js microservices with Kafka?
questions.answer: npm install kafkajs. Producer: send order event to topic 'orders'. Consumer: listen to topic, process in background. Express app: produce to Kafka from routes, consume in worker. Enables async, decoupled communication.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Order processing

questions.title: How do you design event-driven flows for Orders, Payments, and Inventory?
questions.answer: Order Service emits 'order.created'. Payment Service consumes, processes. On success, emits 'payment.completed'. Inventory Service consumes, decrements stock. Each service independent; loosely coupled. Enables scaling per domain.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ eCommerce

questions.title: What topics and partitions do you use for high-volume eCommerce events?
questions.answer: Topics: orders, payments, inventory, notifications. Partitions: scale by order ID (partition order to same partition) for ordering, or scale by volume. Typically 3-10 partitions. Monitor lag.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ High throughput

questions.title: How do you guarantee message delivery (at-least-once, exactly-once)?
questions.answer: At-least-once: enable retries, acks='all'. May duplicate; handle idempotency (idempotency key). Exactly-once: complex, requires transactions + idempotency. Most systems use at-least-once + idempotent handlers.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Order processing

questions.title: How do you handle consumer lag and scaling Kafka consumers?
questions.answer: Monitor consumer lag: Kafka metrics. Increase consumers (up to partition count) to parallelize. Reduce processing time. Auto-scaling: scale up if lag > threshold. Consumer groups balance partitions.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Performance

questions.title: How do you implement event sourcing for order lifecycle management?
questions.answer: Store all order events (created, paid, shipped, delivered) in event log. Rebuild state by replaying. Benefits: audit trail, temporal queries, recovery. Libraries: eventstore, EventStoreDB. Complex but powerful for order systems.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Order history

questions.title: How do you handle distributed transactions across Kafka and SQL?
questions.answer: Saga pattern: order transaction spans multiple services. Choreography: services react to events (loose coupling). Orchestration: central coordinator. For Payment + Inventory: if inventory update fails, publish 'payment.refund' event. Compensate failures.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Order flow

questions.title: How is authentication handled between Customer Portal and Admin Portal?
questions.answer: Single Auth Service issues JWT with role (customer/admin). Both portals send JWT in Authorization header. Backend verifies role for protected routes. Customers see /portal/products; admins see /admin/products.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ NMG eCommerce

questions.title: How do you manage product catalog caching for faster load times?
questions.answer: Cache products in Redis (category, search terms). TTL: 1 hour for volatile, 24h for stable. On product update: invalidate related cache entries. Serve static catalog from CDN. Reduces DB calls 90%+.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Product pages

questions.title: How do you synchronize inventory updates across SQL + MongoDB + Kafka?
questions.answer: Inventory Service source-of-truth in SQL. On update: emit 'inventory.updated' event to Kafka. Product Service (MongoDB) consumes, updates cache. Both services eventually consistent. Kafka ensures delivery.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Multi-DB

questions.title: How do you manage multi-device login and JWT refresh for customers?
questions.answer: Issue access token (1h) + refresh token (7d) on login. Store refresh token in db with device ID. Client stores tokens securely (httpOnly cookie). On expiry: client sends refresh token; server validates device, issues new access token.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Mobile + web

questions.title: How do you optimize checkout APIs during a flash sale?
questions.answer: Cache product prices, apply coupon rules in-memory. Use connection pooling for DB. Implement rate limiting to prevent abuse. Queue checkout requests (Bull). Scale horizontally with load balancer. Async inventory decrement.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Flash sales

questions.title: How do you secure high-traffic endpoints like Add-to-Cart and Checkout?
questions.answer: Auth middleware: verify JWT. Rate limiting: 10 reqs/min per user. Input validation: product ID, quantity. HTTPS only. Helmet headers. Monitor for fraudulent activity (velocity checks).
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Cart/checkout

questions.title: How do you prevent duplicate orders using idempotency keys?
questions.answer: Client generates UUID; includes in request header. Server checks: if exists, return cached response. If new, process, cache result, return. Prevents double-charging on retry. Store in db with 24h TTL.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Payment safety

questions.title: How do you build scalable microservices for product search, offers, and recommendations?
questions.answer: Search Service: Elasticsearch for fast full-text search, faceted filters. Offers Service: Kafka listens to orders, applies rules in-memory. Recommendations: collaborative filtering or content-based, cached. Each scales independently.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ eCommerce features

questions.title: How do you maintain data consistency between Orders Service and Payments Service?
questions.answer: Order Service creates order (status: pending). Calls Payment Service (async via Kafka). Payment succeeds â†’ emits 'payment.completed'. Order Service consumes, updates status. If payment fails, order cancels. Event-driven ensures consistency.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Order-payment

questions.title: How do you handle asynchronous order confirmation using Kafka events?
questions.answer: Order Service creates order, emits 'order.created' to Kafka. Notification Service consumes, sends confirmation email. Payment Service processes. Inventory Service decrements stock. Each service acts independently; eventual consistency.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Order lifecycle

questions.title: What is the difference between REST and SOAP?
questions.answer: REST is an architectural style that uses HTTP verbs and typically JSON over HTTP for lightweight, stateless communication. SOAP is a protocol that uses XML envelopes and has stricter standards (WSDL, WS-*). REST is simpler, cacheable, and preferred for web APIs; SOAP offers built-in WS-security, transactions, and strict contracts, suiting enterprise integrations.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Web APIs
â€¢ Lightweight integrations
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Public JSON APIs
â€¢ Enterprise payment integrations with SOAP

questions.title: Explain the key principles or constraints of a RESTful architecture.
questions.answer: Key constraints: 1) Client-Server separation, 2) Stateless interactions (no server-side session), 3) Cacheable responses, 4) Uniform interface (resources identified by URIs, use of HTTP methods), 5) Layered system (intermediate proxies, gateways), 6) Code on demand (optional). Following these improves scalability, evolvability, and simplicity.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Scalable APIs
â€¢ Separation of concerns
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Public REST endpoints
â€¢ Microservice HTTP APIs

questions.title: What is an API endpoint?
questions.answer: An endpoint is a specific URL (URI) exposed by the API that represents a resource or action (for example /api/products or /api/orders/{id}). Endpoints accept HTTP methods (GET, POST, etc.) and return responses. They are the interface clients call to interact with the system.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Resource access
â€¢ Routing design
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ GET /products, POST /orders

questions.title: What does CRUD stand for and how does it relate to HTTP methods?
questions.answer: CRUD = Create, Read, Update, Delete. Common HTTP mappings: Create -> POST, Read -> GET, Update -> PUT or PATCH, Delete -> DELETE. These conventions map resource lifecycle operations to standard HTTP verbs for predictable APIs.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Resource lifecycles
â€¢ API design
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ POST /users, GET /users/1, PATCH /users/1, DELETE /users/1

questions.title: What is a resource in the context of REST?
questions.answer: A resource is a conceptual mapping to an entity or collection (user, order, product). Resources are identified by URIs and represented in a format like JSON. The API exposes operations on resources via HTTP methods rather than RPC-style actions.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Modeling APIs
â€¢ URL design
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ /products maps to product collection, /products/{id} to single product

questions.title: How do you represent a resource in a RESTful system?
questions.answer: Resources are represented as payloads, typically JSON objects (or XML). Representations include attributes and optionally hypermedia links (HATEOAS) to related resources. Include metadata, links, and careful versioning of fields for backward compatibility.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ JSON product representation with id, name, price, links

questions.title: What is idempotence, and which HTTP methods are idempotent?
questions.answer: An idempotent operation can be applied multiple times without changing the result after the first application. Safe idempotent HTTP methods: GET, PUT, DELETE, HEAD, OPTIONS (GET/DELETE/PUT are idempotent; POST is not idempotent by default). Design APIs so retries of idempotent methods are safe.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ PUT /orders/123 to set order state repeatedly is safe

questions.title: What is the purpose of the OPTIONS HTTP method?
questions.answer: OPTIONS lets a client discover communication options for a resource (allowed methods, CORS preflight responses). Browsers issue OPTIONS preflight requests to check allowed methods and headers for cross-origin requests. Servers should respond with appropriate Allow and CORS headers.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ CORS handling
â€¢ API discovery
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Browser preflight before POST with custom headers

questions.title: Can a REST API be stateful? Explain your reasoning.
questions.answer: By REST constraints, APIs should be stateless (each request contains all required context) to enable scalability and easier load balancing. Stateful APIs store session on server, which violates statelessness and reduces horizontal scalability. In practice, some systems maintain session for convenience, but to be RESTful one should design stateless interactions (e.g., include authentication token in each request).
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Scalability considerations
â€¢ Session design
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Token-based auth for stateless APIs

questions.title: Describe the appropriate use cases for POST, PUT, and PATCH.
questions.answer: POST: create a new subordinate resource (e.g., POST /orders). Non-idempotent. PUT: full replace of a resource at a known URI; idempotent (PUT /users/1 with full object). PATCH: partial update of a resource; semantic partial changes (PATCH /users/1 {"email":...}). Use PUT when client sends full representation; PATCH for partial updates to avoid sending the entire payload.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Create vs update patterns
â€¢ Idempotency
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ POST /products, PUT /products/1, PATCH /products/1/price

questions.title: What is the difference between an HTTP status code 401 and 403?
questions.answer: 401 Unauthorized: request lacks valid authentication credentials (user not authenticated or token expired). 403 Forbidden: authenticated but not authorized to access the resource (permission denied). Use 401 to prompt authentication, 403 to indicate access is denied despite authentication.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Error semantics
â€¢ Auth handling
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ 401 for missing token, 403 for insufficient role

questions.title: When would you use a 201 status code versus a 200 status code?
questions.answer: 201 Created: used when a request successfully creates a resource (usually include Location header with URI of new resource). 200 OK: general success response for retrieval or successful operation that does not create a new resource. Use 201 for POST resource creation, 200 for successful GET or idempotent updates returning content.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Response conventions
â€¢ Creation responses
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ POST /orders -> 201 with Location: /orders/123

questions.title: What do the 3xx status codes represent in a REST context?
questions.answer: 3xx codes indicate redirection. Examples: 301 Moved Permanently, 302 Found (temp redirect), 304 Not Modified (used with caching/conditional requests). In REST APIs, 3xx can be used for resource relocation or for clients to use cache validations (304). For APIs, prefer returning updated resource URIs rather than frequently redirecting.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ 304 when If-None-Match matches ETag

questions.title: What is the difference between a 400 Bad Request and a 422 Unprocessable Entity?
questions.answer: 400 Bad Request: the request is malformed (invalid JSON, missing required syntax). 422 Unprocessable Entity: request well-formed syntactically but semantically invalid (validation errors, business rule violations). Use 422 to return field-level validation errors, 400 for parse/format errors.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ 400 for malformed JSON, 422 for invalid field values

questions.title: Which HTTP status code should be used if a resource is permanently removed?
questions.answer: Use 410 Gone to indicate a resource has been permanently removed and is no longer available. 404 Not Found indicates resource not present but may reappear. 410 explicitly signals permanent removal and can help clients stop requesting or cache the removal.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Deprecated API endpoints permanently removed -> 410

questions.title: What is API versioning and why is it important?
questions.answer: API versioning allows evolving APIs without breaking existing clients. It provides compatibility guarantees, enables gradual migrations, and helps deprecate old behavior safely. Without versioning, changes to field names or semantics can break consumers.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ /v1/users vs /v2/users during migration

questions.title: What are different strategies for versioning a REST API and which is preferred?
questions.answer: Common strategies: 1) URL path (/v1/resource) â€“ explicit and cache-friendly. 2) Query parameter (?version=1) â€“ less visible. 3) Custom header (Accept: application/vnd.myapp.v1+json) â€“ cleaner URIs but harder for browsers and caching. Preferred: URL path for public APIs (simplicity), headers for content negotiation in advanced cases. Choose consistently and document it.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Version migration
â€¢ Client compatibility
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ /api/v1/products remains while /api/v2/products added

questions.title: Should you use query parameters or path variables for uniquely identifying a resource?
questions.answer: Use path variables for resource identity (e.g., /orders/{id}). Use query parameters for filtering, searching, or optional modifiers (e.g., /products?category=shirts&page=2). Keep canonical resource URIs in the path and use query params for non-identifying parameters.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ URI design
â€¢ Resource identification
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ /users/123 vs /users?email=joe@example.com

questions.title: How do you handle nested resources (e.g., retrieving all comments for a specific post)?
questions.answer: Use nested paths to express relationships: GET /posts/{postId}/comments to fetch comments for a post. For large collections, support pagination and possibly a top-level resource /comments?postId={postId} to enable cross-collection queries. Keep nesting shallow to avoid overly deep URIs.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Relationship modeling
â€¢ API ergonomics
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ GET /posts/42/comments?page=2

questions.title: How do you handle filtering, sorting, and pagination in a REST API?
questions.answer: Expose query parameters: filtering (e.g., ?status=active), sorting (e.g., ?sort=-createdAt or sort=price,asc), and pagination (limit/offset or cursor-based: ?page=2&per_page=20 or ?cursor=abc). Prefer cursor pagination for high-scale APIs to avoid offset slowness; use consistent defaults and include metadata (total, next cursor) in responses.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ /products?category=shoes&sort=price&limit=20

questions.title: What are some common data formats used in REST APIs? What are the pros and cons of JSON and XML?
questions.answer: JSON: lightweight, native to JavaScript, compact, easily parsed, preferred for web APIs. XML: verbose, supports schemas (XSD), namespaces, and more robust validation and transformation (XSLT). Use JSON for typical REST APIs; use XML when strict schema, legacy systems, or SOAP integration is required.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Public JSON APIs, enterprise XML integrations

questions.title: How would you secure a RESTful API?
questions.answer: Use HTTPS/TLS, authenticate requests (OAuth2/JWT/API keys), authorize at resource level (RBAC), validate and sanitize inputs, enforce rate limiting, use CORS correctly, log and monitor, store secrets in a secrets manager, and rotate credentials. Use defense-in-depth: API Gateway, WAF, and service-level checks.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ HTTPS + JWT auth + rate limiting in production

questions.title: Explain the difference between authentication and authorization.
questions.answer: Authentication verifies identity (who you are). Authorization determines actions the authenticated identity can perform (what you can do). Both are required: first authenticate the client/user, then check permissions for the requested resource/action.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Security concepts
â€¢ Access control
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Login -> authentication, then role check for admin endpoints

questions.title: What are some common authentication mechanisms used in REST APIs (e.g., Basic Auth, API Keys, OAuth 2.0, JWT)?
questions.answer: Common mechanisms: Basic Auth (username/password over TLS) for simple use; API Keys for service-to-service or low security needs; OAuth2 for delegated authorization flows (authorization code, client credentials); JWT for stateless token-based auth. Choose based on use case: OAuth2 for third-party access, JWT for stateless microservices.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ OAuth2 for social login, JWT for internal APIs

questions.title: What is Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) and how does it work?
questions.answer: CORS is a browser mechanism that controls cross-origin requests. Server responds with Access-Control-Allow-Origin, Access-Control-Allow-Methods, and Access-Control-Allow-Headers. Browsers issue preflight OPTIONS requests for certain cross-origin requests. Properly configure CORS to allow trusted origins and credentials when needed.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Browser APIs
â€¢ Cross-origin calls
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Frontend calling API on different domain requires CORS headers

questions.title: How can you implement caching in a REST API?
questions.answer: Use HTTP caching headers (Cache-Control, Expires) for client/CDN caching; use ETag/Last-Modified for conditional requests; server-side caches (Redis, CDN) for frequently requested data. Choose cache-control directives carefully for data freshness. Invalidate caches on data change or use short TTLs for volatile data.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Cache product catalog in CDN with short TTLs for updates

questions.title: What are ETag and If-None-Match headers used for?
questions.answer: ETag is a response header representing a resource version (hash). Clients send If-None-Match with ETag to ask server to return 304 Not Modified if resource unchanged. This saves bandwidth and improves perceived performance by allowing clients to reuse cached representations.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Conditional requests
â€¢ Bandwidth optimization
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Return 304 when cached product unchanged

questions.title: What is rate limiting and why is it necessary?
questions.answer: Rate limiting restricts number of requests a client can make in a time window to protect APIs from abuse, DoS, and to ensure fair usage. Implement via token bucket, leaky bucket, or fixed window algorithms using Redis for distributed limits. Provide useful headers (X-RateLimit-Limit, X-RateLimit-Remaining) to clients.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Limit 100 req/min per API key

questions.title: How would you structure a consistent error response for your API?
questions.answer: Return JSON with consistent fields: {"error": {"code": "INVALID_INPUT", "message": "Validation failed", "details": [{"field":"email","message":"invalid"}] , "timestamp":"..."}}. Use machine-readable error codes and include human-friendly messages and optional field-level details for clients to program against.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Return structured validation errors for forms

questions.title: Which HTTP status codes are used for server-side errors?
questions.answer: 5xx codes indicate server errors. Common ones: 500 Internal Server Error (generic), 502 Bad Gateway (upstream failure), 503 Service Unavailable (maintenance or overload), 504 Gateway Timeout (upstream timeout). Use appropriate code to signal the nature of the server problem.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Return 503 during maintenance windows

questions.title: What tools do you use to test REST APIs?
questions.answer: Tools: Postman for interactive testing, Newman for CI runs, curl for quick checks, automated tests via supertest (Node), pytest + requests, Pact for contract testing, and load testing tools (k6, JMeter). Use integration tests, contract tests, and end-to-end tests in CI.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Postman collections for QA, Newman in CI pipeline

questions.title: What constitutes a good API contract or documentation?
questions.answer: A good contract includes: clear endpoint list, request/response schemas (JSON Schema or OpenAPI), status codes, error formats, authentication/authorization details, examples, rate limits, versioning policy, and change/deprecation notices. Provide OpenAPI/Swagger spec for machine-readable docs and client generation.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ OpenAPI spec for SDK generation and QA

questions.title: How do you ensure backward compatibility when modifying an existing API?
questions.answer: Strategies: additive changes only (add new fields but keep old ones), deprecate fields with warnings, version the API for breaking changes, use feature flags, provide grace periods and migration guides, support both old and new contracts concurrently, and run contract tests against consumers.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Safe evolution
â€¢ Client stability
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Maintain /v1 while rolling out /v2 and slowly migrate clients

questions.title: What is Microservices Architecture?
questions.answer: Microservices is an architectural pattern where applications are built as loosely coupled, independently deployable services. Each service: handles specific business capability, runs in own process, communicates via APIs/messaging. Benefits: scalability, flexibility, fault isolation. Example: eCommerce = User Service, Product Service, Order Service.
questions.useCases:
â€¢ Large applications
â€¢ Scaling specific features
questions.realTimeUseCases:
â€¢ Netflix
â€¢ Amazon

questions.title: What are the key characteristics of microservices?
questions.answer: 1) Single Responsibility: each service owns one business domain. 2) Independent Deployment: deploy without affecting others. 3) Loose Coupling: minimal dependencies. 4) Communication: REST/gRPC/Kafka. 5) Scalability: scale individual services. 6) Technology Diversity: use different stacks per service. 7) Resilience: failure isolation. 8) Observability: distributed tracing/logging.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Design decisions

questions.title: What problems does microservices architecture solve?
questions.answer: 1) Scalability: scale only services under load (Products vs Payments). 2) Flexibility: different teams own services, deploy independently. 3) Technology Freedom: use Node.js for User Service, Go for Order Service. 4) Resilience: one service failure doesn't crash entire app. 5) Development Speed: teams work parallel. 6) Continuous Deployment: release without system-wide testing.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ System design

questions.title: What are the disadvantages of microservices?
questions.answer: 1) Complexity: network latency, distributed transactions. 2) Operational Overhead: need monitoring, logging, tracing per service. 3) Data Consistency: eventual consistency challenges. 4) Testing: harder to test across services (integration tests). 5) Debugging: request spans multiple services, hard to trace. 6) Network Failures: partial failures, cascading issues. 7) Initial Investment: infrastructure overhead (Kubernetes, Kafka).
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Architecture tradeoffs

questions.title: Monolithic vs Microservices: key differences?
questions.answer: Monolithic: single codebase, single database, shared memory. Deployment: all or nothing. Scaling: scale entire app. Monolith wins: simplicity, consistency, easier testing. Microservices: multiple codebases, multiple databases, network calls. Deployment: independent. Scaling: per-service. Microservices wins: scalability, flexibility. Choice: start monolith, migrate to microservices as scale grows.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Initial design

questions.title: What are the building blocks of microservices architecture?
questions.answer: 1) Services: independent components (User, Order, Payment). 2) API Gateway: single entry point, routes requests. 3) Service Discovery: finds service locations. 4) Load Balancer: distributes traffic. 5) Message Broker: async communication (Kafka, RabbitMQ). 6) Configuration Server: centralized config. 7) Monitoring/Logging: ELK stack, Prometheus. 8) Container Orchestration: Kubernetes.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ System design

questions.title: What is the request flow in microservices architecture?
questions.answer: 1) Client sends request to API Gateway. 2) Gateway authenticates (JWT verification). 3) Gateway routes to target microservice. 4) Service receives request, business logic execution. 5) Service calls dependent services (Order Service â†’ Inventory Service). 6) Service returns response to Gateway. 7) Gateway returns to client. 8) Logging/tracing at each step via correlation ID.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ API flow

questions.title: What communication methods are used between microservices?
questions.answer: 1) Synchronous: REST HTTP calls, gRPC. Order Service calls Payment Service, waits for response. 2) Asynchronous: Message queues (Kafka, RabbitMQ). Order Service publishes 'order.created' event; other services consume. 3) Hybrid: use sync for critical paths, async for notifications. Sync faster but tight coupling; async looser coupling but eventual consistency.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Integration patterns

questions.title: Synchronous vs Asynchronous communication in microservices?
questions.answer: Synchronous: caller waits for response. REST API call: immediate feedback. Pros: simple, immediate consistency. Cons: tight coupling, cascading failures. Asynchronous: caller doesn't wait. Message queue: caller publishes, continues. Pros: loose coupling, resilience. Cons: eventual consistency, harder to debug. Best: use sync for critical flows (payment), async for notifications (email, analytics).
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Design choice

questions.title: What is an API Gateway and why is it essential?
questions.answer: API Gateway: single entry point for all client requests. Functions: 1) Routing: direct to appropriate service. 2) Authentication: verify JWT, prevent unauthorized access. 3) Rate Limiting: prevent abuse. 4) Logging: centralized request logs. 5) Response Aggregation: combine multiple service responses. 6) Load Balancing: distribute traffic. Examples: Kong, AWS API Gateway, Netflix Zuul.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ REST APIs

questions.title: How does API Gateway work internally?
questions.answer: 1) Client sends request to Gateway (URL, headers, body). 2) Gateway checks routing rules: /products â†’ Product Service, /orders â†’ Order Service. 3) Middleware chain: auth â†’ rate limit â†’ logging. 4) Forward request to target service. 5) Service processes, returns response. 6) Gateway may transform response (formatting, data aggregation). 7) Return to client. Decouples clients from backend services; can change service endpoints without client impact.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Request routing

questions.title: What problems does API Gateway solve?
questions.answer: 1) Centralized Authentication: single place to verify JWT (not in each service). 2) Cross-cutting Concerns: logging, rate limiting in one place. 3) Service Discovery Abstraction: clients don't need to know service IPs. 4) Load Balancing: distribute traffic evenly. 5) Response Transformation: aggregate data from multiple services. 6) Security: SSL termination, DDoS protection. 7) Versioning: route /v1/ and /v2/ to different services.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Architecture benefits

questions.title: What are Gateway Filters in microservices?
questions.answer: Filters: interceptors in request/response pipeline. Pre-filters (before forwarding): JWT validation, rate limiting, logging. Post-filters (after response): transform response, add headers. Examples: Spring Cloud Gateway, Kong. Usage: order by priority. Example: auth-filter (pre) â†’ rate-limit-filter (pre) â†’ forward â†’ log-filter (post).
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Request/response handling

questions.title: How do you integrate Service Discovery with API Gateway?
questions.answer: Service Registry: stores service locations (hostname, port). Service Discovery: queries registry to find service IP. Integration: Gateway queries registry to get service endpoint. On service startup: register in registry (Consul, Eureka). On shutdown: deregister. Gateway caches endpoints for performance. Monitors health; removes unhealthy instances.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Service discovery

questions.title: What is the request flow through API Gateway in detail?
questions.answer: 1) Client â†’ Gateway: GET /api/orders/123 + JWT. 2) Gateway Pre-filters: auth-filter validates JWT, adds user to context. 3) Gateway Pre-filters: rate-limit checks quota. 4) Gateway Routes: /orders â†’ Order Service. 5) Order Service: processes request. 6) Order Service â†’ Response: order JSON. 7) Gateway Post-filters: add headers, logging. 8) Gateway â†’ Client: response. Complete flow includes error handling, retries, circuit breaking.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Debugging

questions.title: How do you design error handling and retry logic in API Gateway?
questions.answer: 1) Timeout: if service doesn't respond in 5s, timeout. 2) Retry: retry failed requests (idempotent only). 3) Circuit Breaker: if service fails 5x, stop sending requests (open circuit). 4) Fallback: return cached data or default response. 5) Logging: log all errors for debugging. Example: GET /orders â†’ timeout â†’ retry 2x â†’ circuit open â†’ return cached â†’ client gets response within 10s instead of hanging.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Failure handling

questions.title: What is Service Discovery and why is it needed?
questions.answer: Service Discovery: mechanism to find service instances dynamically. Needed because: microservice instances scale up/down, IP addresses change, hardcoding IPs won't work. Two patterns: 1) Client-side: client queries registry to find service. 2) Server-side: load balancer queries registry. Registry: Consul, Eureka, etcd. Health checks ensure only healthy instances listed.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Scaling infrastructure

questions.title: What is the difference between Service Registry and Service Discovery?
questions.answer: Service Registry: database storing service metadata (name, IP, port, health). Service Discovery: process of finding service from registry. Registry is storage; Discovery is the query mechanism. Analogy: Registry = phone book; Discovery = looking up a number. Both needed: services register themselves (registry); clients/gateways discover (discovery).
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Architecture understanding

questions.title: What are the types of Service Discovery?
questions.answer: 1) Client-side Discovery: client queries registry (Consul, Eureka), gets list, picks one, calls directly. Pros: simple. Cons: logic in client. 2) Server-side Discovery: client calls load balancer; balancer queries registry, routes. Pros: client simple, centralized. Cons: extra hop. 3) DNS-based: use DNS for service lookup. Each type has tradeoffs; server-side preferred for simplicity.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Architecture choice

questions.title: What is Client-side vs Server-side Load Balancing?
questions.answer: Client-side: client queries service registry, gets list of instances, picks one (round-robin), calls directly. Pros: no extra hop. Cons: client logic complexity. Server-side: client calls load balancer; balancer routes to instances. Pros: simple client. Cons: extra network hop. Microservices typically use both: client-side from gateway to services (performance), server-side within service clusters (simplicity).
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Scaling design

questions.title: How does inter-service communication work in microservices?
questions.answer: 1) Service A needs data from Service B. 2) Service A queries Service Discovery: 'find Service B'. 3) Gets list of B instances (e.g., 3 IPs). 4) Service A calls one instance via HTTP/gRPC. 5) Service B processes, returns response. 6) Service A caches/processes response. On failure: retry another instance, apply circuit breaker, fallback.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Communication patterns

questions.title: What is the microservices communication architecture?
questions.answer: Architecture: Client â†’ API Gateway (entry point) â†’ microservices (Product, Order, Payment) â†’ external services. Sync communication: REST within services. Async: Kafka for events. Service Discovery enables dynamic routing. Load Balancing distributes traffic. Circuit Breaker handles failures. Result: scalable, resilient system where services communicate independently.
questions.realTimeUseCases: â€¢ Design pattern

questions.title: What is Load Balancing in microservices?
questions.answer: Load Balancing: distributing incoming traffic across multiple instances. Purpose: 1) Even distribution prevents overload. 2) Fault tolerance if one instance fails. 3) Horizontal scaling (add more instances). Algorithms: Round-robin (in order), Least Connections, IP Hash.
